      <script type="text/javascript">
        window.__PRELOADED_STATE__ = {"abstracts":{"content":[{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"st0005"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"__text__","_":"Hard carbon (HC) is recognized as a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries due to its high capacity and low operating voltage. However, the usage of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder leads to a shortened HC cycle life because of the high reactivity of PVDF toward the carbonate ester-based electrolyte. Herein, we have reported the synthesis of a cellulose nanocrystal (CNC) reinforced chitosan (Ch)-derived free-standing HC anode, which features hydroxyl surface chemistry on HC and flexible framework. The CNC-Ch not only serves as a binder and a substrate but also increases the Na-ions adsorption and diffusion. The CNC content induced the pseudocapacitive behavior and enhanced the cycle stability of the HC anode. The CNC of 6Â % exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 285 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":", an initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 82Â %, and a reversible capacity of 244 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" at a current density of 25Â mAÂ g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" for 5Â cycles. For 100-cycle charge-discharge, it showed excellent cycle stability, retaining 67Â % of its capacity in the first 50Â cycles at 25Â mAÂ g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" and 82Â % in the subsequent 50Â cycles at 50Â mAÂ g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":". This finding suggests that the free-standing HC anode in CNC-Ch presents a new opportunity for the development of a low-cost, stable, flexible, and environmentally sustainable anode for SIB application."}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"sp0055"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"as0005"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"ab0005","lang":"en","class":"author"},"#name":"abstract"},{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"st0010"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Graphical class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab0015" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="as0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0065"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">A free-standing hard carbon anode derived from low content CNC-reinforced chitosan (Ch) matrix.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">The CNC-Ch substrate serves a dual role as both the substrate and binder for hard</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The âˆ’OH functional groups of CNC contribute to the stability of SEI and the cycle life of the hard carbon anode</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">CNC plays a significant role in enhancing the pseudocapacitive/slopping capacity.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab0005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as0005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0055"><span><span>Hard carbon (HC) is recognized as a promising <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a><span> for sodium-ion batteries due to its high capacity and low operating voltage. However, the usage of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a><span> fluoride (PVDF) binder leads to a shortened <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carbon-cycle" title="Learn more about HC cycle from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC cycle</a> life because of the high reactivity of PVDF toward the carbonate ester-based electrolyte. Herein, we have reported the synthesis of a </span></span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/cellulose-nanocrystals" title="Learn more about cellulose nanocrystal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cellulose nanocrystal</a> (CNC) reinforced chitosan (Ch)-derived free-standing HC anode, which features hydroxyl surface chemistry on HC and flexible framework. The CNC-Ch not only serves as a binder and a substrate but also increases the Na-ions adsorption and diffusion. The CNC content induced the pseudocapacitive behavior and enhanced the cycle stability of the HC anode. The CNC of 6&nbsp;% exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 285 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, an initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 82&nbsp;%, and a reversible capacity of 244 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for 5&nbsp;cycles. For 100-cycle charge-discharge, it showed excellent cycle stability, retaining 67&nbsp;% of its capacity in the first 50&nbsp;cycles at 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 82&nbsp;% in the subsequent 50&nbsp;cycles at 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. This finding suggests that the free-standing HC anode in CNC-Ch presents a new opportunity for the development of a low-cost, stable, flexible, and environmentally sustainable anode for SIB application.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0060"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0050"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-ga1.jpg" height="177" alt="Unlabelled Image"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (503KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (503KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24012350"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24012842"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="ks0005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kw0005" class="keyword"><span id="tx0010">Hard carbon</span></div><div id="kw0010" class="keyword"><span id="tx0015">Chitosan</span></div><div id="kw0015" class="keyword"><span id="tx0020">CNC</span></div><div id="kw0020" class="keyword"><span id="tx0025">Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="kw0025" class="keyword"><span id="tx0030">Free-standing anode</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span>Rechargeable batteries are the most popular electrochemical energy storage for electronic devices, electric vehicles, and large-scale energy storage systems (EES), providing both high energy efficiency and a wide <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> range of 30 to 200&nbsp;Wh&nbsp;kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" name="bbb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><span>]. Since 1991, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have dominated the EES due to their high voltage, long lifespan, and high <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0010" name="bbb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. However, the rapidly increasing cost of lithium resource, motivated the researchers to develop the alternative batteries. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are currently being recognized as a low-cost [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0015" name="bbb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0020" name="bbb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>], sustainable [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0020" name="bbb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>], and superior safer compared to LIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0025" name="bbb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0030" name="bbb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a><span>]. Even SIBs have reached research maturity to compete LIBs. In recent years, SIBs have received great attention due to their similar <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> to LIBs [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0035" name="bbb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a><span><span>], abundant element in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/earth-crust" title="Learn more about earth's crust from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">earth's crust</a> and </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/seawater" title="Learn more about seawater from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">seawater</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0040" name="bbb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a><span>], good cycle stability, high <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-conductivity" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a>, and low solubility energy [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0045" name="bbb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>]. However, SIBs present lower energy density than LIBs, despite Paradion Corporation's claim that their SIBs reach an energy density of 160&nbsp;Wh&nbsp;kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0050" name="bbb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a><span><span>]. The finding suitable cathode and <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> that deliver reliable performance for SIBs remains a significant challenge. Prospective anodes for SIBs have been explored, including materials composed of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxides</a>, metal alloys, and carbon [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0055" name="bbb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. However, metal oxides and metal alloys have large volumetric change during battery cycling leading to poor cycle life [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0060" name="bbb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0065" name="bbb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. Currently, carbon-based anode is the most promising for SIBs in a commercial application due to their low-cost, abundant, low potential, and high capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0055" name="bbb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. Non-graphitizable carbon materials, known as hard carbon (HC), has emerged as a promising candidate in the growth of sustainable rechargeable SIBs and green energy. Since its discovery in 2010, SIBs have developed at a rapid rate, with HC becoming a rising star anode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0070" name="bbb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>]. HC is easily derived from abundant biomass waste and possesses the following superior characteristics: high specific capacity, low working voltage, high ionic and electronic conductivities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0075" name="bbb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>], internally well-tailored texture [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0080" name="bbb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>], and large microcrystalline interlayer spacing. HC can be synthesized by pyrolyzing biomass waste at temperatures between 1000 and 1600&nbsp;Â°C. For example, HC derived from rice husks exhibits a discharge capacity of 242 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0085" name="bbb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0090" name="bbb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>], while that from avocados demonstrates 352 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0095" name="bbb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], and shaddock peel-derived HC demonstrates a discharge capacity of 430.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a><span>]. In addition, the surface chemistry of HC can be tailored by the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/heteroatom-doping" title="Learn more about heteroatom doping from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heteroatom doping</a> (nitrogen, phosphorus, and boron) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0105" name="bbb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>] and introducing oxygen functional group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0110" name="bbb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a><span><span>] to enhance sloping capacity and stability of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a><span> interphase (SEI). However, it is worth noting that the process of modifying the <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about HC surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC surface</a> is intricate and time-consuming. Furthermore, it's imperative to consider that the </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span> of HC anode is not only influenced by its intrinsic properties but also by the appropriate binder. PVDF binder has widely applied for carbon-based anode because of its good adhesion and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> in non-aqueous electrolyte for facile transport of Na-ions to the anode surface [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0115" name="bbb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. However, using PVDF as a binder for HC has several drawbacks including low ICE and inferior cycling stability due to pore clogging, thus leading to reduced capacities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0120" name="bbb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>]. The low ICE can be attributed to the decomposition of PVDF partially by reaction at the first cycle and during long-term cycling of charge-discharge [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0125" name="bbb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0130" name="bbb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>]. In addition, the use of <em>N</em>-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) as PVDF solvent where it is: toxic, expensive, and flammable [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0125" name="bbb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0135" name="bbb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>], and its inability to compensate volume expansion of anode particles during charge-discharge cycles, thus leading to binder cracking and loss of conductivity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0115" name="bbb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">Numerous studies have been conducted to enhance the electrochemical performance of HC by employing environmentally friendly binders. Water-based binders, including Na-carboxymethyl cellulose (Na-CMC) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0140" name="bbb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0145" name="bbb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>], Na-alginate (Na-Alg) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0130" name="bbb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0150" name="bbb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>], and polyacrylic acid (PAA) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0155" name="bbb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>], have been extensively investigated in this regard. Unfavorably, Na-CMC and Na-Alg possess rich -OH and -COONa functional groups, which strongly adsorb Na-ions, resulting irreversible de-sodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0160" name="bbb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a><span><span>]. Chitosan (Ch) is an environmentally friendly binder with the potential to effectively bind <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-particle" title="Learn more about HC particles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC particles</a> through intermolecular </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/hydrogen-bonding" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonding</a>, thanks to its abundant -NH and -OH functional groups. However, Ch has not been widely used as an HC binder for SIBs applications. Ch has demonstrated reliability as an electrode binder materials for LIBs, zinc-ion batteries [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0165" name="bbb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0170" name="bbb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0175" name="bbb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0180" name="bbb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0185" name="bbb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a><span>] and <a href="/topics/materials-science/supercapacitors" title="Learn more about supercapacitor from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">supercapacitor</a> applications [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0190" name="bbb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0195" name="bbb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. The works reported that Ch enhance anodes' capacity, solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) stability, cycle stability, and electronic conductivity by the electrons delocalization within the Ï€-Ï€* orbital via the -NH functional group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0185" name="bbb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. Ch is also reported can address expansion issues during charging through hydrogen bonded supramolecular self-healing [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0200" name="bbb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0205" name="bbb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>]. Additionally, Ch reacts with the electrolyte, forming a stable SEI passive layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0210" name="bbb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. Based on the research findings, Ch is predicted to be a promising candidate as an anode binder for SIBs application. Our previous work [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0215" name="bbb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a><span>] has demonstrated that Ch exhibits high potential as a flexible substrate, eliminating Al current collector and the need for additional binders in HC anodes for SIB applications. We have successfully fabricated free-standing HC anodes in a Ch substrate reinforced with <a href="/topics/materials-science/cellulose-nanocrystals" title="Learn more about CNC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CNC</a><span>. This composite exhibited a lower charge transfer resistance compared to that of the PVDF-Al foil. However, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/cellulose-nanocrystals" title="Learn more about CNC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CNC</a> content in the substrate is excessively high, ranging from 10 to 50&nbsp;%, resulting in elevated ionic resistance. These findings suggest that the quantity of CNCs significantly affects the surface chemistry of the HC anode. CNC serves as a reinforcement agent [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0220" name="bbb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>] and offers several advantages, including excellent biocompatibility, improved mechanical properties, a rich contribution of the -OH functional group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0225" name="bbb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>], low cost and light weight [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0230" name="bbb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>]. Peng et al. found that the oxygen-containing functional groups regulate the SEI composition, resulting in a highly conductive, robust, and stable SEI layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0235" name="bbb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. Shan et al. also proved that the presence of the -OH functional groups could trap Na-ions and then promote reversible Na-ions insertion and de-insertion reactions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0240" name="bbb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. The introduction the -OH, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O, and -HOOC functional groups potentially received higher Na-ions adsorption in graphitic structure of HC, as simulated by Nenni et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0105" name="bbb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a><span>]. Fu et al. reported that regulating the -OH chemistry-derived <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanocellulose" title="Learn more about nanocellulose from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanocellulose</a><span> on a free-standing <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about kalium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">kalium</a> vanadium phosphate fluoride (KVPF) cathode surface enhances its capability for K-ions capture, transport, and diffusion in potassium-ion battery applications [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. This demonstrated that the arrangement of oxygen functional groups can indeed alter the chemical properties of the electrode surface.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">Motivated by previous results, we investigated the influence of the CNC in the Ch matrix toward the electrochemical performance of free-standing HC_CNC-Ch used as anodes for SIBs. The synergy between Ch and CNC as HC substrate results in the HC_CNC-Ch anode with the improved mechanical properties, a unique <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a><span>, and controllable surface chemistry by simple functionalization approach, thanks to the contribution of the -OH functional group. The robust hydrogen bonding ability of CNC-Ch enables the formation of a flexible HC_CNC-Ch anode (with more than 5&nbsp;% strain tolerance), featuring a porous network that facilitates rapid diffusion of Na-ions and charge transfer. Simultaneously, it entraps HC particles, eliminating the need for additional binders, current collectors, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/organic-solvents" title="Learn more about organic solvents from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">organic solvents</a>. The adequate amount of CNC effectively captures and transports Na-ions, thereby enhancing the diffusion and adsorption behavior of Na-ions. As a result, HC_CNC-Ch with 6&nbsp;% of CNC exhibits remarkable Na-ions storage performance in terms of high ICE (82&nbsp;%), high reversible capacity (244 mAh g-1 at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1), high retained capacity (82&nbsp;% after 100&nbsp;cycles), and a stable SEI, compared to HC with PVDF binder (HC_PVDF). This finding presents an opportunity to develop HC anode with a simple fabrication, flexible features, environmental friendliness, cost-effectiveness, long-life cycles, and high capacity for SIBs application.</span></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Methods</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span>Hard carbon (HC) used in the study was purchased from Gelon Energy (China). Battery-grade materials, including PVDF, acetylene black (AB), NMP, and a 1&nbsp;M of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> perchlorate (NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span>) electrolyte in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) with a ratio of 1:1, along with a 5&nbsp;% additive of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), were obtained from KGC (Indonesia). Glacial acetic acid was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Those materials were used without further purification. Ch, with a deacetylation degree of 88.5&nbsp;% and a <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/molecular-weight" title="Learn more about molecular weight from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molecular weight</a> of 295&nbsp;kDa was purchased from Biochitosan (Indonesia). CNC was isolated from rice husk (rice mill factory, West Java Indonesia) using the alkaline-acid hydrolysis method, as previously reported [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0215" name="bbb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>].</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Preparation of free-standing HC Anode in CNC-reinforced Ch</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span>A 2&nbsp;wt% of Ch solution was prepared in a 2&nbsp;wt% of acetic acid, and a CNC suspension was added. The mixture was then homogenized using an <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultrasonics" title="Learn more about ultrasonic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ultrasonic</a> homogenizer (UP50H, Hielscher ultrasonic GmbH) for 15&nbsp;min. The CNC content in Ch was varied from 0&nbsp;% to 10&nbsp;% wt., i.e., 0&nbsp;%, 4&nbsp;%, 6&nbsp;%, 8&nbsp;%, and 10&nbsp;%. For each composition of CNCx-Ch (where x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 4, 6, 8, 10&nbsp;%), 4&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’2</sup><span> of HC and 5&nbsp;wt% AB were added. The mixture was then homogenized using an ultrasonic homogenizer for 15&nbsp;min. Subsequently, the mixture was poured into <a href="/topics/materials-science/polystyrene" title="Learn more about polystyrene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polystyrene</a> molds and dried at 40&nbsp;Â°C for 15&nbsp;h to obtain a free-standing HC-CNCx-Ch anode. They were labelled as follows: HC_CNC0-Ch, HC_CNC4-Ch, HC_CNC6-Ch, HC_CNC8-Ch, and HC_CNC10-Ch, representing different levels of CNC content in the Ch matrix.</span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Physicochemical characterization of HC</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The initial selection of commercial HC materials is a crucial stage to meet the specifications for SIBs anode. Several parameters, such as the graphene interlayer spacing (d<sub>002</sub>), I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> ratio, surface area, and identification of functional groups, play significant roles in determining the capacity of different types of HC. d<sub>002</sub><span> was analyzed using a Bruker D8 Advanced <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> instrument equipped with Cu-KÎ± radiation (Î»&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5406&nbsp;Ã…). The XRD measurements were carried out at an operating voltage of 40&nbsp;kV and a filament current of 40&nbsp;mA. Scattered radiation was recorded over the 2Î¸ angle range of 10</span><sup>o</sup> to 70<sup>o</sup> at a scan rate of 0.02Â° s<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a> was performed using a Bruker Senterra II to investigate the ratio of disorder carbon (I</span><sub>D</sub>) intensity to graphene intensity (I<sub>G</sub>). The scanning range of 500â€“3000&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> was employed with a spectral resolution of 4&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. Nitrogen <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/sorption" title="Learn more about sorption from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sorption</a> analysis was conducted using a NOVA 2200e surface area and pore-size analyzer to determine the surface area employing the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore-size distribution was determined from the desorption branch of the isotherm using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model.</span></div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Physicochemical characterization of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span>The tensile test of the HC_CNCx-Ch anodes were conducted using a Tensilon RTG-1250 instrument with a 50&nbsp;N load and a loading rate of 0.1&nbsp;mm/min. The samples were prepared by cutting 5 strips with a width of 5&nbsp;mm each, and the grip distance was set at a constant value of 10&nbsp;mm. The tensile test results provided information on the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultimate-tensile-strength" title="Learn more about tensile strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile strength</a><span> and strain of HC_CNCx-Ch. <a href="/topics/materials-science/tensile-testing" title="Learn more about Tensile testing from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Tensile testing</a> of HC_CNCx-Ch samples were also performed after immersion in a 1&nbsp;M NaClO</span></span><sub>4</sub> electrolyte in EC:DMC (1:1) solution.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span>Morphological observations of the HC_CNCx-Ch anode was conducted using a Hitachi SU3500 scanning <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron microscope</a> (SEM) at 10&nbsp;kV and 40&nbsp;% spot intensity. FTIR analysis was performed to acquire the spectra of HC_CNCx-Ch. The spectra were recorded by scanning within the wavenumber range of 4500â€“400&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at a resolution of 4.0&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, utilizing a Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer (FTIR, Shimadzu Prestige 21, Japan). The contact angle measurements were conducted utilizing a Kyowa DMs-401 contact angle meter (Japan) at ambient temperature. Following the placement of a HC_CNCx-Ch sample (20&nbsp;mm&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;50&nbsp;mm) onto a movable stage, 2&nbsp;Î¼L of 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> electrolyte in EC-DMC (1:1) was dropped onto the surface of the composites. The droplet's shape was subsequently captured on video. Kyowa FAMAS software was subsequently applied to the droplet image to ascertain the droplet contact angle.</div></section><section id="s0035"><h3 id="st0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. Electrochemical performance evaluation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch anode, without a current collector, were evaluated by assembling a 2032-type coin cell in a glove box filled with ultra-high purity N</span><sub>2</sub>. The average mass loading of HC was controlled in the range of 3â€“4&nbsp;mg/cm<sup>2</sup>. For the half-cell test, sodium foil served as the counter and reference electrode, a 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> in EC: DMC (1:1) was used as the electrolyte, and a glass fiber (Whatman, grade GF/C) was utilized as the separator. Galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) measurements were conducted using a Neware CT-4008&nbsp;T (China) with a voltage window of 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;<em>V</em>. Galvanostatic intermittent titration techniques (GITT) measurement was also taken using a Neware CT-4008&nbsp;T under a 20&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1 current pulse with 10&nbsp;min charge/discharge and 40&nbsp;min rest interval within a voltage range 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0155" name="bbb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a><span>]. <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) was performed using a Corrtest CS350 (Wuhan, China) with various scan rate from 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) was analyzed using a Gamry Reference 3000 (US) in the 1&nbsp;MHz â€“ 0.1&nbsp;Hz with perturbation voltage of 5&nbsp;mV. For comparison, HC_PVDF was fabricated by mixing HC, PVDF, and AB in a composition of 85:10:5 to form a slurry. The slurry was then coated onto Al foil and dried at 80&nbsp;Â°C for 24&nbsp;h. Subsequently, the HC_PVDF was cut into a diameter of 16&nbsp;mm and further dried at 120&nbsp;Â°C in a vacuum oven for 4&nbsp;h. The assembling step to create a half-cell was conducted similarly for HC_CNCx-Ch.</span></div></section></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="s0045"><h3 id="st0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Physicochemical characterizations of HC</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075"><span>The HC material employed in this study is a carefully selected commercially available type that meets the specific intrinsic properties necessary for anodes in SIBs. These properties include the degree of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a>, pore type, defects, and functional groups. As a crucial characteristic of the HC material, it should possess a crystalline phase structure with a graphene interlayer spacing (d</span><sub>002</sub>) ranging from 0.36 to 0.40&nbsp;nm. This distance is the site for the sodiation/de-sodiation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. The d<sub>002</sub><span> provides insights into the structural arrangement and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a><span> of the HC material. By employing <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> testing, the d</span></span><sub>002</sub> can be determined using the Bragg equation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0255" name="bbb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>] following eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0005" name="bfo0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="fo0005" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot;
