class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">A free-standing hard carbon anode derived from low content CNC-reinforced chitosan (Ch) matrix.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">The CNC-Ch substrate serves a dual role as both the substrate and binder for hard</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The âˆ’OH functional groups of CNC contribute to the stability of SEI and the cycle life of the hard carbon anode</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">CNC plays a significant role in enhancing the pseudocapacitive/slopping capacity.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab0005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as0005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0055"><span><span>Hard carbon (HC) is recognized as a promising <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a><span> for sodium-ion batteries due to its high capacity and low operating voltage. However, the usage of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a><span> fluoride (PVDF) binder leads to a shortened <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carbon-cycle" title="Learn more about HC cycle from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC cycle</a> life because of the high reactivity of PVDF toward the carbonate ester-based electrolyte. Herein, we have reported the synthesis of a </span></span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/cellulose-nanocrystals" title="Learn more about cellulose nanocrystal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cellulose nanocrystal</a> (CNC) reinforced chitosan (Ch)-derived free-standing HC anode, which features hydroxyl surface chemistry on HC and flexible framework. The CNC-Ch not only serves as a binder and a substrate but also increases the Na-ions adsorption and diffusion. The CNC content induced the pseudocapacitive behavior and enhanced the cycle stability of the HC anode. The CNC of 6&nbsp;% exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 285 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, an initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 82&nbsp;%, and a reversible capacity of 244 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for 5&nbsp;cycles. For 100-cycle charge-discharge, it showed excellent cycle stability, retaining 67&nbsp;% of its capacity in the first 50&nbsp;cycles at 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 82&nbsp;% in the subsequent 50&nbsp;cycles at 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. This finding suggests that the free-standing HC anode in CNC-Ch presents a new opportunity for the development of a low-cost, stable, flexible, and environmentally sustainable anode for SIB application.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0060"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0050"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-ga1.jpg" height="177" alt="Unlabelled Image"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (503KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (503KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24012350"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24012842"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="ks0005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kw0005" class="keyword"><span id="tx0010">Hard carbon</span></div><div id="kw0010" class="keyword"><span id="tx0015">Chitosan</span></div><div id="kw0015" class="keyword"><span id="tx0020">CNC</span></div><div id="kw0020" class="keyword"><span id="tx0025">Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="kw0025" class="keyword"><span id="tx0030">Free-standing anode</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span>Rechargeable batteries are the most popular electrochemical energy storage for electronic devices, electric vehicles, and large-scale energy storage systems (EES), providing both high energy efficiency and a wide <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> range of 30 to 200&nbsp;Wh&nbsp;kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" name="bbb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><span>]. Since 1991, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have dominated the EES due to their high voltage, long lifespan, and high <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0010" name="bbb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. However, the rapidly increasing cost of lithium resource, motivated the researchers to develop the alternative batteries. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are currently being recognized as a low-cost [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0015" name="bbb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0020" name="bbb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>], sustainable [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0020" name="bbb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>], and superior safer compared to LIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0025" name="bbb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0030" name="bbb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a><span>]. Even SIBs have reached research maturity to compete LIBs. In recent years, SIBs have received great attention due to their similar <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> to LIBs [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0035" name="bbb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a><span><span>], abundant element in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/earth-crust" title="Learn more about earth's crust from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">earth's crust</a> and </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/seawater" title="Learn more about seawater from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">seawater</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0040" name="bbb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a><span>], good cycle stability, high <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-conductivity" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a>, and low solubility energy [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0045" name="bbb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>]. However, SIBs present lower energy density than LIBs, despite Paradion Corporation's claim that their SIBs reach an energy density of 160&nbsp;Wh&nbsp;kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0050" name="bbb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a><span><span>]. The finding suitable cathode and <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> that deliver reliable performance for SIBs remains a significant challenge. Prospective anodes for SIBs have been explored, including materials composed of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxides</a>, metal alloys, and carbon [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0055" name="bbb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. However, metal oxides and metal alloys have large volumetric change during battery cycling leading to poor cycle life [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0060" name="bbb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0065" name="bbb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. Currently, carbon-based anode is the most promising for SIBs in a commercial application due to their low-cost, abundant, low potential, and high capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0055" name="bbb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. Non-graphitizable carbon materials, known as hard carbon (HC), has emerged as a promising candidate in the growth of sustainable rechargeable SIBs and green energy. Since its discovery in 2010, SIBs have developed at a rapid rate, with HC becoming a rising star anode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0070" name="bbb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>]. HC is easily derived from abundant biomass waste and possesses the following superior characteristics: high specific capacity, low working voltage, high ionic and electronic conductivities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0075" name="bbb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>], internally well-tailored texture [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0080" name="bbb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>], and large microcrystalline interlayer spacing. HC can be synthesized by pyrolyzing biomass waste at temperatures between 1000 and 1600&nbsp;Â°C. For example, HC derived from rice husks exhibits a discharge capacity of 242 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0085" name="bbb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0090" name="bbb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>], while that from avocados demonstrates 352 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0095" name="bbb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], and shaddock peel-derived HC demonstrates a discharge capacity of 430.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a><span>]. In addition, the surface chemistry of HC can be tailored by the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/heteroatom-doping" title="Learn more about heteroatom doping from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heteroatom doping</a> (nitrogen, phosphorus, and boron) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0105" name="bbb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>] and introducing oxygen functional group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0110" name="bbb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a><span><span>] to enhance sloping capacity and stability of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a><span> interphase (SEI). However, it is worth noting that the process of modifying the <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about HC surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC surface</a> is intricate and time-consuming. Furthermore, it's imperative to consider that the </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span> of HC anode is not only influenced by its intrinsic properties but also by the appropriate binder. PVDF binder has widely applied for carbon-based anode because of its good adhesion and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> in non-aqueous electrolyte for facile transport of Na-ions to the anode surface [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0115" name="bbb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. However, using PVDF as a binder for HC has several drawbacks including low ICE and inferior cycling stability due to pore clogging, thus leading to reduced capacities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0120" name="bbb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>]. The low ICE can be attributed to the decomposition of PVDF partially by reaction at the first cycle and during long-term cycling of charge-discharge [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0125" name="bbb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0130" name="bbb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>]. In addition, the use of <em>N</em>-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) as PVDF solvent where it is: toxic, expensive, and flammable [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0125" name="bbb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0135" name="bbb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>], and its inability to compensate volume expansion of anode particles during charge-discharge cycles, thus leading to binder cracking and loss of conductivity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0115" name="bbb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">Numerous studies have been conducted to enhance the electrochemical performance of HC by employing environmentally friendly binders. Water-based binders, including Na-carboxymethyl cellulose (Na-CMC) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0140" name="bbb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0145" name="bbb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>], Na-alginate (Na-Alg) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0130" name="bbb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0150" name="bbb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>], and polyacrylic acid (PAA) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0155" name="bbb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>], have been extensively investigated in this regard. Unfavorably, Na-CMC and Na-Alg possess rich -OH and -COONa functional groups, which strongly adsorb Na-ions, resulting irreversible de-sodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0160" name="bbb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a><span><span>]. Chitosan (Ch) is an environmentally friendly binder with the potential to effectively bind <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-particle" title="Learn more about HC particles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC particles</a> through intermolecular </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/hydrogen-bonding" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonding</a>, thanks to its abundant -NH and -OH functional groups. However, Ch has not been widely used as an HC binder for SIBs applications. Ch has demonstrated reliability as an electrode binder materials for LIBs, zinc-ion batteries [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0165" name="bbb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0170" name="bbb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0175" name="bbb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0180" name="bbb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0185" name="bbb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a><span>] and <a href="/topics/materials-science/supercapacitors" title="Learn more about supercapacitor from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">supercapacitor</a> applications [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0190" name="bbb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0195" name="bbb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. The works reported that Ch enhance anodes' capacity, solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) stability, cycle stability, and electronic conductivity by the electrons delocalization within the Ï€-Ï€* orbital via the -NH functional group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0185" name="bbb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. Ch is also reported can address expansion issues during charging through hydrogen bonded supramolecular self-healing [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0200" name="bbb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0205" name="bbb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>]. Additionally, Ch reacts with the electrolyte, forming a stable SEI passive layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0210" name="bbb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. Based on the research findings, Ch is predicted to be a promising candidate as an anode binder for SIBs application. Our previous work [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0215" name="bbb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a><span>] has demonstrated that Ch exhibits high potential as a flexible substrate, eliminating Al current collector and the need for additional binders in HC anodes for SIB applications. We have successfully fabricated free-standing HC anodes in a Ch substrate reinforced with <a href="/topics/materials-science/cellulose-nanocrystals" title="Learn more about CNC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CNC</a><span>. This composite exhibited a lower charge transfer resistance compared to that of the PVDF-Al foil. However, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/cellulose-nanocrystals" title="Learn more about CNC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CNC</a> content in the substrate is excessively high, ranging from 10 to 50&nbsp;%, resulting in elevated ionic resistance. These findings suggest that the quantity of CNCs significantly affects the surface chemistry of the HC anode. CNC serves as a reinforcement agent [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0220" name="bbb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>] and offers several advantages, including excellent biocompatibility, improved mechanical properties, a rich contribution of the -OH functional group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0225" name="bbb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>], low cost and light weight [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0230" name="bbb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>]. Peng et al. found that the oxygen-containing functional groups regulate the SEI composition, resulting in a highly conductive, robust, and stable SEI layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0235" name="bbb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. Shan et al. also proved that the presence of the -OH functional groups could trap Na-ions and then promote reversible Na-ions insertion and de-insertion reactions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0240" name="bbb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. The introduction the -OH, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O, and -HOOC functional groups potentially received higher Na-ions adsorption in graphitic structure of HC, as simulated by Nenni et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0105" name="bbb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a><span>]. Fu et al. reported that regulating the -OH chemistry-derived <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanocellulose" title="Learn more about nanocellulose from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanocellulose</a><span> on a free-standing <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about kalium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">kalium</a> vanadium phosphate fluoride (KVPF) cathode surface enhances its capability for K-ions capture, transport, and diffusion in potassium-ion battery applications [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. This demonstrated that the arrangement of oxygen functional groups can indeed alter the chemical properties of the electrode surface.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">Motivated by previous results, we investigated the influence of the CNC in the Ch matrix toward the electrochemical performance of free-standing HC_CNC-Ch used as anodes for SIBs. The synergy between Ch and CNC as HC substrate results in the HC_CNC-Ch anode with the improved mechanical properties, a unique <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a><span>, and controllable surface chemistry by simple functionalization approach, thanks to the contribution of the -OH functional group. The robust hydrogen bonding ability of CNC-Ch enables the formation of a flexible HC_CNC-Ch anode (with more than 5&nbsp;% strain tolerance), featuring a porous network that facilitates rapid diffusion of Na-ions and charge transfer. Simultaneously, it entraps HC particles, eliminating the need for additional binders, current collectors, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/organic-solvents" title="Learn more about organic solvents from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">organic solvents</a>. The adequate amount of CNC effectively captures and transports Na-ions, thereby enhancing the diffusion and adsorption behavior of Na-ions. As a result, HC_CNC-Ch with 6&nbsp;% of CNC exhibits remarkable Na-ions storage performance in terms of high ICE (82&nbsp;%), high reversible capacity (244 mAh g-1 at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1), high retained capacity (82&nbsp;% after 100&nbsp;cycles), and a stable SEI, compared to HC with PVDF binder (HC_PVDF). This finding presents an opportunity to develop HC anode with a simple fabrication, flexible features, environmental friendliness, cost-effectiveness, long-life cycles, and high capacity for SIBs application.</span></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Methods</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span>Hard carbon (HC) used in the study was purchased from Gelon Energy (China). Battery-grade materials, including PVDF, acetylene black (AB), NMP, and a 1&nbsp;M of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> perchlorate (NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span>) electrolyte in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) with a ratio of 1:1, along with a 5&nbsp;% additive of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), were obtained from KGC (Indonesia). Glacial acetic acid was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Those materials were used without further purification. Ch, with a deacetylation degree of 88.5&nbsp;% and a <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/molecular-weight" title="Learn more about molecular weight from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molecular weight</a> of 295&nbsp;kDa was purchased from Biochitosan (Indonesia). CNC was isolated from rice husk (rice mill factory, West Java Indonesia) using the alkaline-acid hydrolysis method, as previously reported [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0215" name="bbb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>].</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Preparation of free-standing HC Anode in CNC-reinforced Ch</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span>A 2&nbsp;wt% of Ch solution was prepared in a 2&nbsp;wt% of acetic acid, and a CNC suspension was added. The mixture was then homogenized using an <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultrasonics" title="Learn more about ultrasonic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ultrasonic</a> homogenizer (UP50H, Hielscher ultrasonic GmbH) for 15&nbsp;min. The CNC content in Ch was varied from 0&nbsp;% to 10&nbsp;% wt., i.e., 0&nbsp;%, 4&nbsp;%, 6&nbsp;%, 8&nbsp;%, and 10&nbsp;%. For each composition of CNCx-Ch (where x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 4, 6, 8, 10&nbsp;%), 4&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’2</sup><span> of HC and 5&nbsp;wt% AB were added. The mixture was then homogenized using an ultrasonic homogenizer for 15&nbsp;min. Subsequently, the mixture was poured into <a href="/topics/materials-science/polystyrene" title="Learn more about polystyrene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polystyrene</a> molds and dried at 40&nbsp;Â°C for 15&nbsp;h to obtain a free-standing HC-CNCx-Ch anode. They were labelled as follows: HC_CNC0-Ch, HC_CNC4-Ch, HC_CNC6-Ch, HC_CNC8-Ch, and HC_CNC10-Ch, representing different levels of CNC content in the Ch matrix.</span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Physicochemical characterization of HC</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The initial selection of commercial HC materials is a crucial stage to meet the specifications for SIBs anode. Several parameters, such as the graphene interlayer spacing (d<sub>002</sub>), I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> ratio, surface area, and identification of functional groups, play significant roles in determining the capacity of different types of HC. d<sub>002</sub><span> was analyzed using a Bruker D8 Advanced <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> instrument equipped with Cu-KÎ± radiation (Î»&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5406&nbsp;Ã…). The XRD measurements were carried out at an operating voltage of 40&nbsp;kV and a filament current of 40&nbsp;mA. Scattered radiation was recorded over the 2Î¸ angle range of 10</span><sup>o</sup> to 70<sup>o</sup> at a scan rate of 0.02Â° s<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a> was performed using a Bruker Senterra II to investigate the ratio of disorder carbon (I</span><sub>D</sub>) intensity to graphene intensity (I<sub>G</sub>). The scanning range of 500â€“3000&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> was employed with a spectral resolution of 4&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. Nitrogen <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/sorption" title="Learn more about sorption from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sorption</a> analysis was conducted using a NOVA 2200e surface area and pore-size analyzer to determine the surface area employing the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore-size distribution was determined from the desorption branch of the isotherm using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model.</span></div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Physicochemical characterization of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span>The tensile test of the HC_CNCx-Ch anodes were conducted using a Tensilon RTG-1250 instrument with a 50&nbsp;N load and a loading rate of 0.1&nbsp;mm/min. The samples were prepared by cutting 5 strips with a width of 5&nbsp;mm each, and the grip distance was set at a constant value of 10&nbsp;mm. The tensile test results provided information on the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultimate-tensile-strength" title="Learn more about tensile strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile strength</a><span> and strain of HC_CNCx-Ch. <a href="/topics/materials-science/tensile-testing" title="Learn more about Tensile testing from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Tensile testing</a> of HC_CNCx-Ch samples were also performed after immersion in a 1&nbsp;M NaClO</span></span><sub>4</sub> electrolyte in EC:DMC (1:1) solution.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span>Morphological observations of the HC_CNCx-Ch anode was conducted using a Hitachi SU3500 scanning <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron microscope</a> (SEM) at 10&nbsp;kV and 40&nbsp;% spot intensity. FTIR analysis was performed to acquire the spectra of HC_CNCx-Ch. The spectra were recorded by scanning within the wavenumber range of 4500â€“400&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at a resolution of 4.0&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, utilizing a Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer (FTIR, Shimadzu Prestige 21, Japan). The contact angle measurements were conducted utilizing a Kyowa DMs-401 contact angle meter (Japan) at ambient temperature. Following the placement of a HC_CNCx-Ch sample (20&nbsp;mm&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;50&nbsp;mm) onto a movable stage, 2&nbsp;Î¼L of 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> electrolyte in EC-DMC (1:1) was dropped onto the surface of the composites. The droplet's shape was subsequently captured on video. Kyowa FAMAS software was subsequently applied to the droplet image to ascertain the droplet contact angle.</div></section><section id="s0035"><h3 id="st0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. Electrochemical performance evaluation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch anode, without a current collector, were evaluated by assembling a 2032-type coin cell in a glove box filled with ultra-high purity N</span><sub>2</sub>. The average mass loading of HC was controlled in the range of 3â€“4&nbsp;mg/cm<sup>2</sup>. For the half-cell test, sodium foil served as the counter and reference electrode, a 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> in EC: DMC (1:1) was used as the electrolyte, and a glass fiber (Whatman, grade GF/C) was utilized as the separator. Galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) measurements were conducted using a Neware CT-4008&nbsp;T (China) with a voltage window of 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;<em>V</em>. Galvanostatic intermittent titration techniques (GITT) measurement was also taken using a Neware CT-4008&nbsp;T under a 20&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1 current pulse with 10&nbsp;min charge/discharge and 40&nbsp;min rest interval within a voltage range 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0155" name="bbb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a><span>]. <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) was performed using a Corrtest CS350 (Wuhan, China) with various scan rate from 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) was analyzed using a Gamry Reference 3000 (US) in the 1&nbsp;MHz â€“ 0.1&nbsp;Hz with perturbation voltage of 5&nbsp;mV. For comparison, HC_PVDF was fabricated by mixing HC, PVDF, and AB in a composition of 85:10:5 to form a slurry. The slurry was then coated onto Al foil and dried at 80&nbsp;Â°C for 24&nbsp;h. Subsequently, the HC_PVDF was cut into a diameter of 16&nbsp;mm and further dried at 120&nbsp;Â°C in a vacuum oven for 4&nbsp;h. The assembling step to create a half-cell was conducted similarly for HC_CNCx-Ch.</span></div></section></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="s0045"><h3 id="st0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Physicochemical characterizations of HC</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075"><span>The HC material employed in this study is a carefully selected commercially available type that meets the specific intrinsic properties necessary for anodes in SIBs. These properties include the degree of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a>, pore type, defects, and functional groups. As a crucial characteristic of the HC material, it should possess a crystalline phase structure with a graphene interlayer spacing (d</span><sub>002</sub>) ranging from 0.36 to 0.40&nbsp;nm. This distance is the site for the sodiation/de-sodiation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. The d<sub>002</sub><span> provides insights into the structural arrangement and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a><span> of the HC material. By employing <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> testing, the d</span></span><sub>002</sub> can be determined using the Bragg equation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0255" name="bbb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>] following eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0005" name="bfo0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="fo0005" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>d</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>002</mn></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>n</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>.</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BB;</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>sin</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B8;</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="12.312ex" height="3.471ex" viewBox="0 -995.6 5300.9 1494.4" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.158ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-64"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(556,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30" x="500" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32" x="1001" y="0"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1995,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2774,0)"><g transform="translate(397,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="2008" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(502,412)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(393,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(590,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BB"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(60,-403)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(520,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-73"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-69" x="394" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6E" x="673" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1556,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B8"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">d</mi><mn is="true">002</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mo is="true">.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î»</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mo is="true">sin</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î¸</mi></mrow></mfrac></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">d</mi><mn is="true">002</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mo is="true">.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î»</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mo is="true">sin</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î¸</mi></mrow></mfrac></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">Here, n represents the diffraction order (typically 1), Î» denotes the X-ray wavelength (1.5406&nbsp;Ã…), and Î¸ indicates the diffraction angle. Based on the measurement, Fig. S1(b) reveals that HC possesses a structure consisting of randomly oriented graphene layers at the peak (2Î¸&nbsp;=&nbsp;23.8Â°) and graphite domain at the peak (2Î¸&nbsp;=&nbsp;26.5Â°). Applying the Bragg equation, the d<sub>002</sub> is determined to be 0.37&nbsp;nm. This value is sufficient to facilitate the sodiation/de-sodiation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><span>In addition, the morphology of HC was also checked using SEM and Fig. S1(a) shows the HC morphology with the irregular shape particles. The crystallinity of HC was analyzed using <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a><span>. Fig. S1(c) displays the two narrow peaks of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectrum</a> at 1349.5&nbsp;cm</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 1597&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> which are related to the D band of disordered graphite and the G band of crystalline graphite, respectively. The ratio of G peak intensity and D peak intensity (I<sub>G</sub>/I<sub>D</sub>) can indicate the ordering degree and defect concentration of HC. The obtained ratio of I<sub>G</sub>/I<sub>D</sub> is 0.71, indicating that the portion of disordered graphite is more dominant than crystalline graphite.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">In term of surface characteristic, the N<sub>2</sub> isothermal curve (Fig. S1(d)) indicates that the HC material has non-porous characteristics, as evident from non-porous SEM image, relatively small adsorption volume, and low surface area (8.93&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup><span>/g). According to the BET test results, the HC material has a <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-volume" title="Learn more about pore volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore volume</a> of 0.032&nbsp;cm</span><sup>3</sup><span>/g and a pore distribution of 15&nbsp;nm (Fig. S1(e)). Non-porous HC particles are believed to form aggregates that create <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a><span>. The aggregation characteristics of mesopores are manifested by the formation of a hysteresis desorption curve. The low specific surface area of HC is advantageous for minimizing the growth of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about SEI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEI</a> on the anode surface [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0260" name="bbb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>]. Concerning the role of HC as an anode in SIBs, the presence of HC aggregates forming mesopores contributes to an increase in battery capacity, particularly the sloping capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0265" name="bbb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>]. Pore characteristics influence the storage performance of Na-ions by providing active sites and shortening the Na-ions diffusion distance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0270" name="bbb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. Based on the physicochemical characterization results, it can be concluded that this HC materials meets the requirements to serve as an anode for SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0050"><h3 id="st0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Physicochemical characterizations of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">Free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch anodes was successfully fabricated using water-based casting techniques by incorporating CNC-reinforced Ch (CNC-Ch) which serves as both a flexible substrate and a binder for the HC and AB particles. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (a) illustrates a thin layer of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes produced with various amount of CNC. The corresponding morphologies are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (b). As depicted in Fig. S2, Ch envelops and integrates HC particles, while CNC bridges between HC particles. Based on FTIR results at <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>, the surface chemistry of pristine HC provide strong <a href="/topics/materials-science/hydrogen-bonding" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonding</a> with CNCx-Ch due to -OH functional group interaction, leading higher cohesiveness [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0275" name="bbb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr1.jpg" height="216" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="ca0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (285KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (285KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0005"><p id="sp0005"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. a) Preparation of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes, b) representative <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a> images of HC_CNC6-Ch (top and bottom surface), and c) visual image of a flexible of free-standing HC_CNC6-Ch anodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><span>All HC_CNCx-Ch anode's surface possesses a similar pattern (Fig. S3 and Fig. S4) and unique <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a>, with HC particles uniformly distributed over the bottom surface and AB particles dispersed on the opposite side. The surface of HC_CNCx-Ch with the exposed HC side creates high porosity that can be utilized as an electrolyte reservoir and facilitate Na-ion transport. Typically, porosity formation occurs during water-based drying [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0275" name="bbb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>]. Additionally, the integration of HC particles into the CNCx-Ch substrate results in a highly flexible anode, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (c).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(a)<span> presents the results of simple peel testing represented by HC_CNC6-Ch. In a simple peel test using adhesive tape, HC_PVDF is detached from the <a href="/topics/materials-science/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminium foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminium foil</a> and adheres to the adhesive tape, while HC_CNC6-Ch only peeled off at the edge of the adhesive tape. It indicates that the CNC6-Ch substrates maintained the structural integrity of HC.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr2.jpg" height="208" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="ca0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (322KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (322KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0010"><p id="sp0010"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>a) Simple peel testing of HC_PVDF vs HC_CNC6-Ch, b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/tensile-testing" title="Learn more about Tensile testing from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Tensile testing</a> of the free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch before and after immersion in NaClO</span><sub>4</sub> electrolyte.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110"><span>The tensile testing was also performed to study strain and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultimate-tensile-strength" title="Learn more about tensile strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile strength</a> of HC_CNCx-Ch. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(b) presents the <a href="/topics/materials-science/ultimate-tensile-strength" title="Learn more about tensile strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile strength</a> HC_CNCx-Ch anodes exhibit an upward trend with increasing CNC content, rising from 2.66&nbsp;MPa at 0&nbsp;wt% CNC to 5.44&nbsp;MPa at 10&nbsp;wt% CNC. This augmentation is attributed to the strengthening effect of CNC on the Ch matrix. On the other hand, the addition of CNC content to the HC_CNCx-Ch anode has a minimal impact on strain. However, CNC content ranging from 0&nbsp;% to 6&nbsp;% surpasses the critical strain limit of 5&nbsp;%, classifying it as a flexible anode [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0280" name="bbb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. The immersion of HC_CNCx-Ch in 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> electrolyte, EC:DMC (1:1), significantly affects strain. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a> (b), the strain of the HC_CNCx-Ch anode reaches 17â€“41.5&nbsp;%. This outcome arises from the absorption of the EC:DMC solvent by the CNC-Ch substrate, causing swelling and enhancing the mobility of the Ch polymer chains [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0285" name="bbb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a><span>]. Consequently, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/plastic-deformation" title="Learn more about plastic deformation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">plastic deformation</a><span> of HC_CNCx-Ch becomes more pronounced under <a href="/topics/materials-science/tensile-loads" title="Learn more about tensile load from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile load</a>, leading to increased strain.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">Further characterizations were carried out to observe the surface chemistry of HC particle and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes using FT-IR. FT-IR analysis was recorded to confirm the functional groups of pristine HC particles and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>. Evidently, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/infrared-spectra" title="Learn more about IR spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">IR spectra</a> of pristine HC particles reveals the presence of functional groups of -OH and -NH in low intensity at 3429&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 1557&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, respectively. These functional groups typically originate from the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> residues of biomass precursors at temperatures below 1500&nbsp;Â°C [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" name="bbb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0295" name="bbb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a><span><span>]. The presence of -OH and -NH groups on the <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about HC surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC surface</a> influences its surface chemistry, strengthens the intermolecular hydrogen bonding with the substrate, and enhances </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> in polar electrolytes. The stretching of -OH or primary -NH, -CH, the in-plane bending of primary -NH, and C-O-C are each represented in the spectra of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes by distinct infrared (IR) peaks at 3429&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 2924&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 1557&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and 1078&nbsp;cm-1, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0300" name="bbb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">60</span></span></a>]. Primarily, the -OH functional group is present in Ch and CNC. Conversely, the -NH functional group is specifically identified as having its source in the Ch compound.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr3.jpg" height="311" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="ca0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (360KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (360KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0015"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. FT-IR spectra of <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-particle" title="Learn more about HC particles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC particles</a> and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The gradual increase in the intensity of the -OH stretching vibration observed between 3429&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for HC_CNCx-Ch, can be assigned to the additional contribution of -OH functional group from the increased CNC. The FTIR profiles of HC_CNCx-Ch show characteristics like its substrate which represented by CNC10-Ch. From FT-IR peaks, the most influential functional groups on HC_CNCx-Ch are -OH and -NH.</div></section><section id="s0055"><h3 id="st0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Electrochemical performance of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125"><span>The electrochemical energy storage behavior of the HC_CNCx-Ch anodes in a half-cell configuration was further investigated through electrochemical measurements utilizing GCD, CV, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> instruments. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span> presents the half-cell configurations for Na || HC_CNCx-Ch and Na || HC_PVDF. The shiny surface of the HC_CNCx-Ch, which is predominantly composed of HC particles, is exposed to the electrolyte. In contrast, its reverse side directly contacts the positive coin case. The open circuit voltage (OCV) data reveals that the HC_CNCx-Ch anode half-cell generates a voltage above 2&nbsp;V, even in the absence of a current collector, and its OCV is comparable to that of HC_PVDF. This coin cell can power a 2&nbsp;V <a href="/topics/materials-science/led-lamp" title="Learn more about LED lamp from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">LED lamp</a> when the OCV surpasses 2.2&nbsp;V. The OCV value serves as an indicator of the availability of active sites for the adsorption and diffusion of Na-ions, reflecting the electrochemical behavior at equilibrium [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0305" name="bbb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. Nevertheless, due to the internal resistance of the half-cell, the OCV value remains consistently lower than the standard Na<sup>+</sup>/Na voltage (2.7&nbsp;V).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr4.jpg" height="137" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="ca0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (131KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (131KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0020"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. The half-cell setup for: a) Na || free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch anode without Al foil current collector, b) Na || HC_PVDF.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0130">As a binder, PVDF is frequently utilized in commercial anodes. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of utilizing CNCx-Ch as both a substrate and binder on the performance of HC, in comparison to the commercial PVDF binder. The specific capacity, rate capability, Na-ion storage mechanism, and cycle stability of HC_CNCx-Ch were evaluated in comparison to HC_PVDF via galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) measurements. These measurements were performed using a 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> electrolyte in an EC:DMC solvent (1:1) within the potential window of 0.01 to 2.5&nbsp;V at different current densities. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a> (a-f) depict the results of GCD performed at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> over 5&nbsp;cycles. HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch have demonstrated comparatively high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 79â€“82&nbsp;% in comparison to other publications [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0310" name="bbb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0315" name="bbb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0320" name="bbb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a>]. This can be attributed to the favourable characteristics of HC, including a small specific surface area, a limited level of active functional groups, and an adequate d<sub>002</sub> distance for sodiation/de-sodiation. The ICE refers to the initial stored capacity calculated from the ratio of charge capacity to discharge capacity. The irreversible capacity indicates the loss of capacity experienced in the initial cycle, generally associated with several factors, such as the formation of a SEI on the anode surface, entrapment of Na-ions at graphene edges, and defects in the graphene planes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" name="bbb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>]. HC_PVDF exhibits a higher initial specific capacity compared to HC_CNCx-Ch. However, the cycle stability of HC_PVDF continuously decreases over five cycles. In contrast, HC_CNCx-Ch appears to be significantly more reversible than HC_PVDF. This characteristic indicates that the binder type plays a crucial role in the Na-ions storage system at the beginning of the cycle and in cycle stability. At a voltage range of 1 to 0.45&nbsp;V, the formation of an SEI layer on the anode surface is primarily responsible for the initial cycle capacity decrease [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. As illustrated in Fig. S5, the dQ/dV vs voltage (V) curve confirms the formation of SEI by displaying a distinct cathodic peak at 0.49&nbsp;V for HC_PVDF and&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.4&nbsp;V for HC_CNCx-Ch, which signifies the electrolyte reduction. According to Kulova et al., the composition and structure of the SEI at the HC anode undergo primarily within the initial 10â€“20&nbsp;cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0325" name="bbb0325" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0325"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">65</span></span></a>]. This evolution is a result of the SEI's instability, which tends to increase due to the decomposition of deposited electrolytes. The overpotential of 0.04&nbsp;V that is detected during the transition from discharge to charge processes in the first cycle of HC_PVDF provides additional evidence for the low stability of the SEI layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0330" name="bbb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>]. It is hypothesized that the instability of the SEI layer may be attributed to the inherently weak properties of PVDF, namely: (1) the pronounced reactivity of PVDF toward ester-based electrolytes, and (2) the tendency of PVDF to facilitate the formation of SEI deposits comprising porous Na<sub>x</sub>C and Na-organic compounds. Such phenomena could lead to a reduction in capacity and an increase in charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" name="bbb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0315" name="bbb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr5.jpg" height="291" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="ca0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (535KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (535KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0025"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. GCD profiles of the: a) HC_PVDF, b) HC_CNC0-Ch, c) HC_CNC4-Ch, d) HC_CNC6-Ch, e) HC_CNC8-Ch, f) HC_CNC10-Ch at current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The high reversibility capacity observed in HC_CNCx-Ch anodes suggests that their performance is significantly influenced by the incorporation of Ch and various CNC materials. The process of sodiation and de-sodiation, exhibiting high reversibility, is affected by the quantity of CNCs, particularly by the contribution of -OH functional groups. The -OH functional groups play a pivotal role in facilitating the adsorption of Na-ions and their sodiation into the HC lattice. During the initial five charge-discharge cycles, the HC_CNCx-Ch anode demonstrates a high reversibility. Specifically, HC_CNC6-Ch exhibits the highest discharge capacity, reaching 284 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, surpassing the discharge capacities of HC_CNC8-Ch (254 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), HC_CNC4-Ch (237 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), HC_CNC0-Ch (236 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), and HC_CNC10-Ch (226 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). By the fifth cycle, HC_CNC6-Ch achieves the highest reversible capacity of 244 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, maintaining a capacity retention of 86&nbsp;%. The range of irreversible capacity for all HC_CNCx-Ch variants lies between 14&nbsp;% to 21&nbsp;%, primarily attributable to the formation of the SEI layer, the entrapment of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a> within defects, and the presence of -NH/-OH functional groups.
