[</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0335" name="bbb0335" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">67</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140"><span>Furthermore, the GCD profiles was employed to study the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> energy storage mechanism in HC. The total capacities of HC_P</span><em>V</em><span>DF and HC_CNCx-Ch originate from the combined contributions of plateau capacity and sloping capacity. The sloping capacity is observed within the voltage range of 2.5&nbsp;V to 0.1&nbsp;V, indicating the adsorption of Na-ions on the surface of HC or the filling of HC mesoporous. Conversely, the plateau capacity is identified through GCD profiles ranging from 0.1&nbsp;V to 0.01&nbsp;V, indicating sodiation process into graphene interlayer and <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopore from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopore</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. Notably, the capacity of HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch is predominantly governed by the plateau capacity. This mechanism aligns with that Jin et al. proposed [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0340" name="bbb0340" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0340"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">68</span></span></a>]. The ability of CNCx-Ch substrates in improving cycle stability of HC is due to the best synergy of -OH and -NH functional groups in adsorbing Na-ions and distributing them homogeneously on HC surfaces [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0345" name="bbb0345" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0345"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>]. The -OH functional group has a self-healing ability through strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding to maintain the integrity of HC particles during volume expansion and stabilize the SEI layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0350" name="bbb0350" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0350"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">70</span></span></a>]. Appropriate -OH substituents promote reversible sodiation and de-sodiation reaction [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0240" name="bbb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">Based on the GCD profile, it has been observed that incorporating 6&nbsp;wt% CNC exhibits the most favourable synergy with Ch in terms of enhancing the specific capacity, reversible capacity, and cyclic stability of HC. However, the addition of more than 6&nbsp;wt% CNC can lead to a decrease in capacity which is attributed to the high affinity of the -OH functional groups. These functional groups are prone to trapping a more significant number of Na-ions, leading to irreversible de-sodiation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0355" name="bbb0355" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0355"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">71</span></span></a>]. Despande et al. proved that Na-ions' interaction with cellulose without water is purely ionic [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0360" name="bbb0360" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0360"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">72</span></span></a>]. Therefore, it is crucial to control the CNC content in HC_CNC-Ch.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0150">The rate capability shows the reversible capacity of an electrode at different current density. Herein, the rate capability of the HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes was performed at various current densities including 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (a). At a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, more Na-ions are stored in the HC material, which can be attributed to diffusion-dominant contribution. With increasing current density, there is inadequate time for Na-ions to effectively diffuse into the graphene layer. The specific capacity tends to decrease as the current density increases, resulting the higher polarization [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0075" name="bbb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>] which reduce the charge transfer Na<sup>+</sup>/Na. The reaction kinetics of Na-ions primarily occurs through pseudocapacitive mechanisms on the surface of HC, as well as within its pores or defects. This behavior is evident by the decline in specific capacity as the current density rises. The rate capability results demonstrate that both HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch exhibit favourable reversible capacity at current densities ranging from 25 to 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. HC-CNC10-Ch exhibit a higher specific capacity than HC_PVDF and among HC_CNCx-Ch at high current density due to the increased CNC contribution. The -OH functional group contribution of CNC provides the capacitive effect at the anode surface, resulting in higher capacity and cycle stability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0365" name="bbb0365" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0365"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">73</span></span></a>]. However, when the current density surpasses over 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the charge-discharge process becomes swift, leading to significant degradation in HC performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0370" name="bbb0370" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0370"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">74</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr6.jpg" height="191" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="ca0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (414KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (414KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0030"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. a) Rate capability at various current density from 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1 to 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1; b) cycle stability of HC_PVDF dan HC_CNCx-Ch at current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">The GCD profile results for 50&nbsp;cycles, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (b), at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1, reveal a significant reduction in the discharge capacity for HC_PVDF, dropping from 316 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 31 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. In the subsequent 50&nbsp;cycles at a current density of 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, only a retained capacity of 1.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is observed. This capacity fading is suspected to be due to the continuous growth of the SEI layer during cycling, associated with irreversible electrolyte decomposition and surface degradation of HC_PVDF. This result aligns with the increased R<sub>ct</sub> observed on the Nyquist plot after 100&nbsp;cycles. In contrast, HC_CNCx-Ch demonstrates superior electrochemical performance for up to 100&nbsp;cycles in terms of cycle stability, reversible capacity, and retained capacity compared to HC_PVDF, thanks to the -OH functional group in CNC which is effective for facilitating the Na<sup>+</sup> movement during the charge-discharge cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0375" name="bbb0375" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0375"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">75</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (b) shows that the highest electrochemical performance is achieved by HC_CNC6-Ch, which is in good agreement with its high reversible CV cycles (Fig. S6) and its lower R<sub>SEI</sub>/R<sub>ct</sub> after 100&nbsp;cycles (Fig. S7). HC_CNC6-Ch exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 285 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and decrease to 190 mAh g-1 at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for 50&nbsp;cycles. Over the next 50&nbsp;cycles, as the current density is increased by 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, a retained capacity of 90 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (82&nbsp;%) is achieved. At the higher current density of 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, HC_CNCx-Ch showed the higher capacity than HC_PVDF as shown in Fig. S8. This higher electrochemical performance of HC_CNCx-Ch resembles with the previous finding by Fu et al. which regulate the electrode surface with -OH functional group-derived <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanocellulose" title="Learn more about nanocellulose from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanocellulose</a> to facilitate K-ion capture and improve transport kinetic, leading to increase its capacity and life-cycle [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. However, it is crucial to control the amount of CNC, as an excess of -OH groups may impede de-sodiation and lead to a reduction in capacity, as suggested by Mittal et al [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0345" name="bbb0345" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0345"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>]. In this study, the optimal electrochemical performance for HC was achieved with a 6&nbsp;% CNC contribution.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">The electrochemical behavior of HC_CNCx-Ch were further analyzed by CV techniques in the potential window of 0.01â€“2.0&nbsp;V using 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> (EC:DMC, 1:1) electrolyte. Fig. S6 displays the CV curves of the half-cell of HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch at scan rate of 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for 4&nbsp;cycles. Two sharp peaks are observed in the CV curves for both HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch, confirming the reversible sodiation/de-sodiation mechanism of Na<sup>+</sup>/Na in the graphene interlayer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165"><span class="display"><span id="fo0010" class="formula"><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi is="true">de</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mtext is="true">sodiation</mtext><mo is="true">:</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">NaC</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub><mspace width="2em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">âž”</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mo is="true">âˆ’</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mi is="true">de</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mtext is="true">sodiation</mtext><mo is="true">:</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">NaC</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub><mspace width="2em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">âž”</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mo is="true">âˆ’</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">The reversible sodiation occurs at 0.01&nbsp;V, meanwhile, the reversible de-sodiation take places at 0.12&nbsp;V for HC_PVDF and 0.2â€“0.44&nbsp;V for HC_CNCx-Ch. The HC_CNC6-Ch, HC_CNC8-Ch, and HC_CNC10-Ch exhibited higher reversibility reactions, which showed by the overlapped CV profiles in subsequent cycles, corresponding with high-capacity retention of anode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0135" name="bbb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. The irreversible peak of HC_PVDF appears in the initial cathodic cycle, which is attributed to the electrolyte decomposition or SEI formation.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0180">Furthermore, the energy storage mechanism of HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch, can be predicted by determining the b-value from the log peak currents (i) vs log the scan rate (Ï…), as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(b) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(e), in accordance with Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0020" name="bfo0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a> and Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0025" name="bfo0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>. The Power law dependence of the current response was used to identify the anode kinetics based on CV curves at various scan rates from 0.2 to 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0380" name="bbb0380" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0380"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[76]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0385" name="bbb0385" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0385"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[77]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0390" name="bbb0390" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0390"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[78]</span></span></a>]. The total stored current (i) in HC is originated from: 1) the faradaic current in the HC bulk (i<sub>b</sub>), known as diffusion current, 2) the faradaic current on HC surface (i<sub>s</sub>), known as pseudocapacitive current, and 3) the nonfaradaic current of double layer effect [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0135" name="bbb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0390" name="bbb0390" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0390"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">78</span></span></a>].<span class="display"><span id="fo0020" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5952,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6730,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-62"></use></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7703,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8983,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28" x="0" y="0"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C5"></use></g><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29" x="930" y="0"></use></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">b</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi></mfenced></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-5"><math><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">b</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi></mfenced></math></script></span></span></span><span>where the a and b are obtained by plotting log(i) versus log(Ï…). The b-value of 1 indicates a pseudocapacitive-dominated process, signifying fast surface <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> and double layer effect. Meanwhile, the b-value of 0.5 suggests a diffusion-dominated process, implying sodiation reaction within the HC lattice. The b-value of 0.75 is associated with the kinetics of the reaction proportionally contributed by both diffusion and pseudocapacitive-controlled process. For cathodic reaction, the calculated b-value of HC P</span><em>V</em>DF and HC_CNC6-Ch are 0.57 and 0.50, respectively, indicating the diffusion-dominated process. Meanwhile, for anodic reaction, the calculated b-value of HC PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch are 0.63 and 0.73, respectively, which indicate the kinetic anodic reaction governed by both diffusion and pseudocapacitive-controlled mechanisms.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr7.jpg" height="431" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="ca0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (553KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (553KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0035"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves at various scan rates from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> for a) HC_PVDF and d) HC_CNC6-Ch; the linier relationship between log i vs log Ï… for b) HC_PVDF and e) HC_CNC6-Ch; the capacity contribution at various scan rates from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for c) HC_PVDF and f) HC_CNC6-Ch.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">Further calculation of diffusion and pseudocapacitive contributions at a certain scan rate can be utilized Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0030" name="bfo0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a> and Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0035" name="bfo0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>. The total voltammetric current is the sum of the diffusion current and the pseudocapacitive current.<span class="display"><span id="fo0030" class="formula"><span class="label">(4)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-6-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mfenced open=&quot;(&quot; close=&quot;)&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="fo0035" class="formula"><span class="label">(5)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-7-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mfenced open=&quot;(&quot; close=&quot;)&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi></mfenced><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C5;</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C5;</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="23.771ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 10234.8 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(278,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28" x="0" y="0"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-56"></use></g><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29" x="1140" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1808,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4288,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5344,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6327,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C5"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(540,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8251,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(9252,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">V</mi></mfenced><mo is="true">/</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-7"><math><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">V</mi></mfenced><mo is="true">/</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></math></script></span></span></span>k<sub>1</sub>Ï… and k<sub>2</sub>Ï…<sup>1/2</sup> correspond to the current contribution from the pseudocapacitive process and the diffusion process, respectively. Using Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0035" name="bfo0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>, the constant k<sub>1</sub> and k<sub>2</sub> are evaluated from the slope and intercept of a linier plot of i(V)/Ï…<sup>1/2</sup> vs Ï…<sup>1/2</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a> (c) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a> (f) provide a quantitative analysis of the capacity contribution of HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch concerning increasing scan rate.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">At a scan rate of 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the electrochemical kinetics of HC_PVDF are primarily governed by a 78&nbsp;% diffusion-dominant process and a 22&nbsp;% pseudocapacitive process. The distinct sharp peak observed in the HC_P<em>V</em>DF anodic peak (at 0.12&nbsp;V) is associated with the de-sodiation reaction kinetics. Conversely, the broad peak in the HC_CNC6-Ch graph signifies an increase in pseudocapacitive kinetics, attributed to the presence of CNC. In the case of HC_CNC6-Ch, the contributions of pseudocapacitive and diffusion processes are 34&nbsp;% and 66&nbsp;%, respectively. In this regard, the -OH functional group in CNC trap Na-ions on the surface, resulting in an increased pseudocapacitive current through functional group adsorption and electrical double-layer formation. Zhifei et al. simulated that the bond energy of Na-ion at the surface involved 1.08&nbsp;eV, whereas at pristine HC, it achieved 0.529&nbsp;eV [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0395" name="bbb0395" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0395"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">79</span></span></a>]. As a result, the voltammetric current released in HC_CNC6-Ch tends to be lower than in HC_PVDF, resulting in a wider anodic peak. Furthermore, increasing the scan rate leads to a higher pseudocapacitive current (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(a)), derived from an increase in double-layer size due to the adsorption mechanism on the surface. Based on this reason, the results are aligned with the b-slope value of 0.73 in the anodic reaction, leading to an increase in pseudocapacitive contribution. This explains why the HC_CNC-Ch peak appears wider compared to HC_PVDF in the anodic peak range of 0.2â€“0.44&nbsp;V. This observation raises the suspicion that -OH functional groups strongly influence pseudocapacitive effects during the anodic reaction. Other researchers have demonstrated that oxygen functional groups enhance ion adsorption [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>] and induces surface capacitance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0235" name="bbb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0195">EIS measurements were performed to investigate the internal resistance of half-cell system both before and after cycling. The ohmic resistance or bulk resistance (R<sub>b</sub>) represents the resistance of electrolyte, separator, and current collector [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0400" name="bbb0400" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0400"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">80</span></span></a>]. The solid electrolyte interphase resistance (R<sub>SEI</sub>) is associated with a thin layer that forms over the anode surface during the initial charge-discharge and is generated by the decomposition of the electrolyte. On the surface of active material, charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) arises due to faradaic reactions. Another significant component, Warburg impedance (W), is the resistance linked to the diffusion process, typically observed at low frequencies around 20&nbsp;Hz to 0.01&nbsp;Hz. Conversely, R<sub>b</sub> is observed at high frequencies. The electrical double layer (EDL) is formed at the interface of SEI and the anode surface, manifesting a constant phase element (CPE). The presence of the CPE correlates with the EDL formation on the porous surface. The anode undergoes the electrochemical kinetics steps, namely: 1) ionic charge transfer through the electrolyte to the anode surface, 2) ion diffusion through the SEI layer, 3) charge transfer at the interlayer between the anode surface and SEI, 4) ionic diffusion inside the anode, 5) phase transfer leading to new phase transformations associated with the pseudocapacitive behavior of the anode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0405" name="bbb0405" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0405"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">81</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0200">The Echem Analyst software was utilized to analyze the EIS spectra in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>(a)<span> to determine the equivalent circuit model, which signifies the resistance encountered throughout the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a>. All anodes displayed low R</span><sub>b</sub><span> as indicated in Table S2, attributed to their lyophilic tendencies, which were determined through contact angle analysis (Fig. S11). HC_PVDF demonstrates excellent <a href="/topics/materials-science/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> with ester-based electrolytes, enhancing its reactivity with these electrolytes and facilitating the formation of a SEI layer. As a result, the resistance of HC_PVDF witnesses a significant increase after 100&nbsp;cycles. The R</span><sub>SEI</sub> surged from 43 Ohm to 722 Ohm, while the R<sub>ct</sub> rose from 12.55 Ohm to 363.7 Ohm. The growth of the SEI on HC_PVDF is evidenced by the decreased capacity seen in its GCD profile. Fig. S8(b) reveals several microcracks on the SEI surface, indicative of uncompensated volume expansion during cycling. In contrast, both R<sub>SEI</sub> and R<sub>ct</sub> for HC_CNC6-Ch only saw a sixfold increase after 100&nbsp;cycles. This indicates that the presence of the -OH functional group on HC_CNC6-Ch plays a crucial role in the surface chemistry of the HC anode, aiding in the stabilization of the SEI and charge transfer. The stable and homogenous SEI film on the HC_CNC6-Ch surface is depicted in Fig. S8. Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) analysis spots shows the accumulation of NaClO<sub>4</sub>, indicating the adsorption of NaClO<sub>4</sub> within the void spaces of the HC_CNC6-Ch (Fig. S9). In the Nyquist plot in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>(a), the SEI semicircles for both HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch are not distinctly visible, due to the semicircle curves of SEI and charge transfer overlapping.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr8.jpg" height="442" alt="Fig. 8" aria-describedby="ca0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (533KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image for HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch, b) Warburg coefficient of Z<sub>real</sub> against Ï‰<sup>-1/2</sup> before and after 100&nbsp;cycles of charge-discharge for HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0205"><span>The Warburg impedance at low-frequency region were used to calculate the apparent <a The <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-9-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; A higher <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-10-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; Moreover, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-11-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ïƒ</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-13"><math><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">R</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">T</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">A</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">F</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ïƒ</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math></script></span></span></span><span>where R, T, A, n, F, C, and Ïƒ are the gas constant, the absolute temperature, the surface area of the anode, the number <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about of electrons transfers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">of electrons transfers</a>, the Faraday constant, the Na-ions concentration, and Warburg coefficient, respectively. An increase in the Ïƒ value signifies a substantial reduction in the diffusion rate. At 100 charge-discharge cycles, the Ïƒ value of PVDF increased substantially from 39.45 to 857, whereas the Ïƒ value of HC_CNC6-Ch decreased substantially from 186 to 4.73.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0215">The determination of diffusion rate was also concluded through GITT analysis, in addition to the EIS method. To acquire quantitative values of the chemical diffusion coefficients of ions in solid electrodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0415" name="bbb0415" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0415"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">83</span></span></a>], the GITT method has been widely implemented. Following Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0050" name="bfo0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>, the GITT method calculated the <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" The Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0050" name="bfo0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0050"><span class="anchor-text">85</span></span></a>]</td></tr><tr><td>HC derived oatmeal_PVDF</td><td>10<sup>âˆ’14</sup>â€“10<sup>âˆ’16</sup></td><td>N/A</td><td>[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0430" name="bbb0430" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0430"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">86</span></span></a>]</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0230">After 100&nbsp;cycles, the <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-23-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Na</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>app</mi></msubsup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.414ex" height="3.24ex" viewBox="0 -896.2 2331 1395" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.158ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,482)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70" x="529" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70" x="1033" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-419)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61" x="803" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(942,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-23"><math><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></script></span> of HC_PVDF reduces considerably from 5.69&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’12</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 1.20&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’14</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, according to EIS method and 7.5&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’08</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 10<sup>âˆ’8</sup>â€“10<sup>âˆ’12</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> according to GITT method. This decrease is attributed to an increase in SEI thickness and provides much higher resistance for the diffusion of Na-ions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0435" name="bbb0435" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0435"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">87</span></span></a>]. In contrast, the <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-24-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Na</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>app</mi></msubsup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.414ex" height="3.24ex" viewBox="0 -896.2 2331 1395" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.158ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,482)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70" x="529" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70" x="1033" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-419)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61" x="803" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(942,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-24"><math><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></script></span> of HC_CNC6-Ch from EIS method increases from 4.81&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’14</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 3.96&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’10</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 5.1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’08</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 10<sup>âˆ’8</sup>â€“10<sup>âˆ’12</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> according to GITT method, which is higher than the values reported in previous research studies, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0005" name="bt0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>. Before cycling, Na-ions have far more difficult diffusing through the HC_CNC6-Ch anode than HC_PVDF. It is believed that Na-ions interact strongly with the -OH functional groups present in the early stages. As the cycling progresses, they allow Na-ions to diffuse faster inside the bulk of the HC material. Based on the <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-25-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Na</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>app</mi></msubsup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.414ex" height="3.24ex" viewBox="0 -896.2 2331 1395" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.158ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,482)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70" x="529" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70" x="1033" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-419)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61" x="803" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(942,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-25"><math><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></script></span>, we can conclude that the presence of -OH functional groups considerably aided the rise of Na-ions diffusion in HC electrode, particularly at the CNC content of 6&nbsp;wt%.</div></section></section><section id="s0060"><h2 id="st0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0235">In conclusion, this study has effectively demonstrated the superior performance of a free-standing HC anode in a CNC-Ch substrate for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), negating the need for a current collector and additional binder. CNC is crucial, acting as a reinforcement agent and contributing âˆ’OH functional groups, thereby enhancing the electrochemical properties of HC anodes. Optimal CNC concentration not only stabilizes the SEI but also facilitates charge transfer and enhances Na-ions diffusion at the HC anode.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0240">Incorporating 6&nbsp;% CNC into HC_CNCx-Ch optimally synergizes with Ch, yielding superior electrochemical performance characterized by a high initial discharge capacity (285 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), ICE of 82&nbsp;%, reversible capacity (244 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) at 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> over the first five cycles, extending the cycle life, and increasing diffusion rate for a long cycle. This capacity, cycle stability, retention, and diffusion rate surpass those of the HC_PVDF anode. This research provides insights into high-performance HC anode design by integrating functional groups into the substrate.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0245">The findings of this research present promising opportunities for the development of environmentally friendly SIBs with high-performance features. The bendable nature of the free-standing HC_CNC6-Ch anode offers opportunities to create flexible SIBs, catering to various applications and providing new possibilities in the field of energy storage.</div></section><section id="s0065"><h2 id="st0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0250"><strong>Dewi Idamayanti:</strong> Writing â€“ original draft, Methodology, Investigation, Conceptualization, Funding acquisition. <strong>Achmad Rochliadi:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Validation, Supervision. <strong>Muhammad Iqbal:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization, Validation. <strong>Zikri Noer:</strong> Software, Formal analysis. <strong>Rizki Febrian:</strong> Software, Formal analysis. <strong>Ni Luh Wulan Septiani:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Validation. <strong>Bambang Sunendar Purwasasmita:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Conceptualization. <strong>Brian Yuliarto:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Conceptualization. <strong>Ahmad Nuruddin:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Validation, Conceptualization.</div></section></div><section id="coi0005"><h2 id="st0095" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0255">The authors declare the following financial interests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing interests: Dewi Idamayanti reports financial support was provided by The Indonesia Endowment Funds for Education (LPDP). u-font-sans">ACS Omega, 3 (2018), pp. 9945-9955, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsomega.8b01407" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1021/acsomega.8b01407</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (5)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0079642524001701"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Advanced hard carbon materials for practical applications of sodium-ion batteries developed by combined experimental, computational, and data analysis approaches</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Progress in Materials Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">Hard carbon materials are considered one of the ideal anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, the practical application of hard carbon materials is limited by complex microstructures and imprecise preparation techniques. On the one hand, advanced hard carbon materials are widely developed through computational simulations and experimental research. On the other hand, the emerging database of precursors âˆ’ preparation parameters âˆ’ microstructures âˆ’ and electrochemical performance has grown fast as more and more research has been reported. The database is greatly beneficial to reducing the trial-and-error nature of the experiments and verifying the reliability of the computational results. In this review, we summarize the rapid development of high-performance hard carbon materials by combining experimental, computational, and data analysis approaches. Focusing on: 1) summarizing the types of precursors and preparation methods to search the development of highly promising precursors and efficient preparation methods, 2) discussing the evolution rule of microstructure parameters and elucidating the correspondence between microstructures and sodium storage mechanisms, 3) revealing the relationship between microstructure characteristics and electrochemical performance of hard carbon, and 4) summarizing the utility potential of various modification strategies on hard carbon. Finally, we outline the main advances and future perspectives of hard carbon in SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0016236124012894"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Biomass derived hard carbon materials for sodium ion battery anodes: Exploring the influence of carbon source on structure and sodium storage performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Fuel</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Compared to the scarce resources of lithium-ion batteries, sodium ion batteries have gradually become an ideal carrier for large-scale energy storage systems due to their abundant raw material resources. In recent years, hard carbon as an anode material for sodium ion batteries has attracted much attention. Biomass materials have become an ideal hard carbon precursor due to their natural and renewable advantages. This article evaluates the effect of hard carbon derived from three types of biomass waste (peanut shell, coffee grounds, and sugarcane bagasse) on the electrochemical performance of sodium ion batteries through pre carbonization pyrolysis method. The three materials exhibit different structures and surface functional group contents. Compared with coffee grounds and sugarcane bagasse, peanut shell-derived hard carbon has lower structural ordering and smaller specific surface area, and exhibits a higher initial Coulombic efficiency of 53.84&nbsp;%. The initial reversible capacity of the HC-P electrode is 203.6 mAh/g, and the Coulombic efficiency of the electrode is close to 100&nbsp;% with a reversible capacity of 127.1 mAh/g and a capacity retention of 81.4&nbsp;% after cycling 100 at 1C current. The excellent electrochemical properties of HC-P can be attributed to its higher C=O bond content, larger layer spacing and lamellar structure.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1088/2516-1083/adbff0" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Lithium-ion to sodium-ion batteries transitioning: trends, analysis and innovative technologies prospects in EV application</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Progress in Energy</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.3390/polysaccharides6010005" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Polysaccharides: The Sustainable Foreground in Energy Storage class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
