is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>sin</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B8;</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="12.312ex" height="3.471ex" viewBox="0 -995.6 5300.9 1494.4" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.158ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-64"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(556,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30" x="500" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32" x="1001" y="0"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1995,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2774,0)"><g transform="translate(397,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="2008" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(502,412)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(393,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(590,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BB"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(60,-403)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(520,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-73"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-69" x="394" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6E" x="673" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1556,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B8"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">d</mi><mn is="true">002</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mo is="true">.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î»</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mo is="true">sin</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î¸</mi></mrow></mfrac></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">d</mi><mn is="true">002</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mo is="true">.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î»</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mo is="true">sin</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î¸</mi></mrow></mfrac></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">Here, n represents the diffraction order (typically 1), Î» denotes the X-ray wavelength (1.5406&nbsp;Ã…), and Î¸ indicates the diffraction angle. Based on the measurement, Fig. S1(b) reveals that HC possesses a structure consisting of randomly oriented graphene layers at the peak (2Î¸&nbsp;=&nbsp;23.8Â°) and graphite domain at the peak (2Î¸&nbsp;=&nbsp;26.5Â°). Applying the Bragg equation, the d<sub>002</sub> is determined to be 0.37&nbsp;nm. This value is sufficient to facilitate the sodiation/de-sodiation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><span>In addition, the morphology of HC was also checked using SEM and Fig. S1(a) shows the HC morphology with the irregular shape particles. The crystallinity of HC was analyzed using <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a><span>. Fig. S1(c) displays the two narrow peaks of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectrum</a> at 1349.5&nbsp;cm</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 1597&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> which are related to the D band of disordered graphite and the G band of crystalline graphite, respectively. The ratio of G peak intensity and D peak intensity (I<sub>G</sub>/I<sub>D</sub>) can indicate the ordering degree and defect concentration of HC. The obtained ratio of I<sub>G</sub>/I<sub>D</sub> is 0.71, indicating that the portion of disordered graphite is more dominant than crystalline graphite.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">In term of surface characteristic, the N<sub>2</sub> isothermal curve (Fig. S1(d)) indicates that the HC material has non-porous characteristics, as evident from non-porous SEM image, relatively small adsorption volume, and low surface area (8.93&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup><span>/g). According to the BET test results, the HC material has a <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-volume" title="Learn more about pore volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore volume</a> of 0.032&nbsp;cm</span><sup>3</sup><span>/g and a pore distribution of 15&nbsp;nm (Fig. S1(e)). Non-porous HC particles are believed to form aggregates that create <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a><span>. The aggregation characteristics of mesopores are manifested by the formation of a hysteresis desorption curve. The low specific surface area of HC is advantageous for minimizing the growth of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about SEI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEI</a> on the anode surface [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0260" name="bbb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>]. Concerning the role of HC as an anode in SIBs, the presence of HC aggregates forming mesopores contributes to an increase in battery capacity, particularly the sloping capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0265" name="bbb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>]. Pore characteristics influence the storage performance of Na-ions by providing active sites and shortening the Na-ions diffusion distance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0270" name="bbb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. Based on the physicochemical characterization results, it can be concluded that this HC materials meets the requirements to serve as an anode for SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0050"><h3 id="st0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Physicochemical characterizations of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">Free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch anodes was successfully fabricated using water-based casting techniques by incorporating CNC-reinforced Ch (CNC-Ch) which serves as both a flexible substrate and a binder for the HC and AB particles. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (a) illustrates a thin layer of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes produced with various amount of CNC. The corresponding morphologies are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (b). As depicted in Fig. S2, Ch envelops and integrates HC particles, while CNC bridges between HC particles. Based on FTIR results at <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>, the surface chemistry of pristine HC provide strong <a href="/topics/materials-science/hydrogen-bonding" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonding</a> with CNCx-Ch due to -OH functional group interaction, leading higher cohesiveness [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0275" name="bbb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr1.jpg" height="216" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="ca0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (285KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (285KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0005"><p id="sp0005"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. a) Preparation of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes, b) representative <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a> images of HC_CNC6-Ch (top and bottom surface), and c) visual image of a flexible of free-standing HC_CNC6-Ch anodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><span>All HC_CNCx-Ch anode's surface possesses a similar pattern (Fig. S3 and Fig. S4) and unique <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a>, with HC particles uniformly distributed over the bottom surface and AB particles dispersed on the opposite side. The surface of HC_CNCx-Ch with the exposed HC side creates high porosity that can be utilized as an electrolyte reservoir and facilitate Na-ion transport. Typically, porosity formation occurs during water-based drying [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0275" name="bbb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>]. Additionally, the integration of HC particles into the CNCx-Ch substrate results in a highly flexible anode, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (c).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(a)<span> presents the results of simple peel testing represented by HC_CNC6-Ch. In a simple peel test using adhesive tape, HC_PVDF is detached from the <a href="/topics/materials-science/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminium foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminium foil</a> and adheres to the adhesive tape, while HC_CNC6-Ch only peeled off at the edge of the adhesive tape. It indicates that the CNC6-Ch substrates maintained the structural integrity of HC.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr2.jpg" height="208" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="ca0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (322KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (322KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0010"><p id="sp0010"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>a) Simple peel testing of HC_PVDF vs HC_CNC6-Ch, b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/tensile-testing" title="Learn more about Tensile testing from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Tensile testing</a> of the free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch before and after immersion in NaClO</span><sub>4</sub> electrolyte.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110"><span>The tensile testing was also performed to study strain and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultimate-tensile-strength" title="Learn more about tensile strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile strength</a> of HC_CNCx-Ch. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(b) presents the <a href="/topics/materials-science/ultimate-tensile-strength" title="Learn more about tensile strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile strength</a> HC_CNCx-Ch anodes exhibit an upward trend with increasing CNC content, rising from 2.66&nbsp;MPa at 0&nbsp;wt% CNC to 5.44&nbsp;MPa at 10&nbsp;wt% CNC. This augmentation is attributed to the strengthening effect of CNC on the Ch matrix. On the other hand, the addition of CNC content to the HC_CNCx-Ch anode has a minimal impact on strain. However, CNC content ranging from 0&nbsp;% to 6&nbsp;% surpasses the critical strain limit of 5&nbsp;%, classifying it as a flexible anode [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0280" name="bbb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. The immersion of HC_CNCx-Ch in 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> electrolyte, EC:DMC (1:1), significantly affects strain. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a> (b), the strain of the HC_CNCx-Ch anode reaches 17â€“41.5&nbsp;%. This outcome arises from the absorption of the EC:DMC solvent by the CNC-Ch substrate, causing swelling and enhancing the mobility of the Ch polymer chains [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0285" name="bbb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a><span>]. Consequently, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/plastic-deformation" title="Learn more about plastic deformation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">plastic deformation</a><span> of HC_CNCx-Ch becomes more pronounced under <a href="/topics/materials-science/tensile-loads" title="Learn more about tensile load from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile load</a>, leading to increased strain.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">Further characterizations were carried out to observe the surface chemistry of HC particle and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes using FT-IR. FT-IR analysis was recorded to confirm the functional groups of pristine HC particles and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>. Evidently, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/infrared-spectra" title="Learn more about IR spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">IR spectra</a> of pristine HC particles reveals the presence of functional groups of -OH and -NH in low intensity at 3429&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 1557&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, respectively. These functional groups typically originate from the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> residues of biomass precursors at temperatures below 1500&nbsp;Â°C [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" name="bbb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0295" name="bbb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a><span><span>]. The presence of -OH and -NH groups on the <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about HC surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC surface</a> influences its surface chemistry, strengthens the intermolecular hydrogen bonding with the substrate, and enhances </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> in polar electrolytes. The stretching of -OH or primary -NH, -CH, the in-plane bending of primary -NH, and C-O-C are each represented in the spectra of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes by distinct infrared (IR) peaks at 3429&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 2924&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 1557&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and 1078&nbsp;cm-1, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0300" name="bbb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">60</span></span></a>]. Primarily, the -OH functional group is present in Ch and CNC. Conversely, the -NH functional group is specifically identified as having its source in the Ch compound.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr3.jpg" height="311" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="ca0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (360KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (360KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0015"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. FT-IR spectra of <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-particle" title="Learn more about HC particles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC particles</a> and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The gradual increase in the intensity of the -OH stretching vibration observed between 3429&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for HC_CNCx-Ch, can be assigned to the additional contribution of -OH functional group from the increased CNC. The FTIR profiles of HC_CNCx-Ch show characteristics like its substrate which represented by CNC10-Ch. From FT-IR peaks, the most influential functional groups on HC_CNCx-Ch are -OH and -NH.</div></section><section id="s0055"><h3 id="st0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Electrochemical performance of HC_CNCx-Ch anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125"><span>The electrochemical energy storage behavior of the HC_CNCx-Ch anodes in a half-cell configuration was further investigated through electrochemical measurements utilizing GCD, CV, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> instruments. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span> presents the half-cell configurations for Na || HC_CNCx-Ch and Na || HC_PVDF. The shiny surface of the HC_CNCx-Ch, which is predominantly composed of HC particles, is exposed to the electrolyte. In contrast, its reverse side directly contacts the positive coin case. The open circuit voltage (OCV) data reveals that the HC_CNCx-Ch anode half-cell generates a voltage above 2&nbsp;V, even in the absence of a current collector, and its OCV is comparable to that of HC_PVDF. This coin cell can power a 2&nbsp;V <a href="/topics/materials-science/led-lamp" title="Learn more about LED lamp from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">LED lamp</a> when the OCV surpasses 2.2&nbsp;V. The OCV value serves as an indicator of the availability of active sites for the adsorption and diffusion of Na-ions, reflecting the electrochemical behavior at equilibrium [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0305" name="bbb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. Nevertheless, due to the internal resistance of the half-cell, the OCV value remains consistently lower than the standard Na<sup>+</sup>/Na voltage (2.7&nbsp;V).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr4.jpg" height="137" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="ca0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (131KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (131KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0020"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. The half-cell setup for: a) Na || free-standing HC_CNCx-Ch anode without Al foil current collector, b) Na || HC_PVDF.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0130">As a binder, PVDF is frequently utilized in commercial anodes. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of utilizing CNCx-Ch as both a substrate and binder on the performance of HC, in comparison to the commercial PVDF binder. The specific capacity, rate capability, Na-ion storage mechanism, and cycle stability of HC_CNCx-Ch were evaluated in comparison to HC_PVDF via galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) measurements. These measurements were performed using a 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> electrolyte in an EC:DMC solvent (1:1) within the potential window of 0.01 to 2.5&nbsp;V at different current densities. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a> (a-f) depict the results of GCD performed at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> over 5&nbsp;cycles. HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch have demonstrated comparatively high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 79â€“82&nbsp;% in comparison to other publications [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0310" name="bbb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0315" name="bbb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0320" name="bbb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a>]. This can be attributed to the favourable characteristics of HC, including a small specific surface area, a limited level of active functional groups, and an adequate d<sub>002</sub> distance for sodiation/de-sodiation. The ICE refers to the initial stored capacity calculated from the ratio of charge capacity to discharge capacity. The irreversible capacity indicates the loss of capacity experienced in the initial cycle, generally associated with several factors, such as the formation of a SEI on the anode surface, entrapment of Na-ions at graphene edges, and defects in the graphene planes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" name="bbb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>]. HC_PVDF exhibits a higher initial specific capacity compared to HC_CNCx-Ch. However, the cycle stability of HC_PVDF continuously decreases over five cycles. In contrast, HC_CNCx-Ch appears to be significantly more reversible than HC_PVDF. This characteristic indicates that the binder type plays a crucial role in the Na-ions storage system at the beginning of the cycle and in cycle stability. At a voltage range of 1 to 0.45&nbsp;V, the formation of an SEI layer on the anode surface is primarily responsible for the initial cycle capacity decrease [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. As illustrated in Fig. S5, the dQ/dV vs voltage (V) curve confirms the formation of SEI by displaying a distinct cathodic peak at 0.49&nbsp;V for HC_PVDF and&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.4&nbsp;V for HC_CNCx-Ch, which signifies the electrolyte reduction. According to Kulova et al., the composition and structure of the SEI at the HC anode undergo primarily within the initial 10â€“20&nbsp;cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0325" name="bbb0325" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0325"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">65</span></span></a>]. This evolution is a result of the SEI's instability, which tends to increase due to the decomposition of deposited electrolytes. The overpotential of 0.04&nbsp;V that is detected during the transition from discharge to charge processes in the first cycle of HC_PVDF provides additional evidence for the low stability of the SEI layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0330" name="bbb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>]. It is hypothesized that the instability of the SEI layer may be attributed to the inherently weak properties of PVDF, namely: (1) the pronounced reactivity of PVDF toward ester-based electrolytes, and (2) the tendency of PVDF to facilitate the formation of SEI deposits comprising porous Na<sub>x</sub>C and Na-organic compounds. Such phenomena could lead to a reduction in capacity and an increase in charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" name="bbb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0315" name="bbb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr5.jpg" height="291" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="ca0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (535KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (535KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0025"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. GCD profiles of the: a) HC_PVDF, b) HC_CNC0-Ch, c) HC_CNC4-Ch, d) HC_CNC6-Ch, e) HC_CNC8-Ch, f) HC_CNC10-Ch at current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The high reversibility capacity observed in HC_CNCx-Ch anodes suggests that their performance is significantly influenced by the incorporation of Ch and various CNC materials. The process of sodiation and de-sodiation, exhibiting high reversibility, is affected by the quantity of CNCs, particularly by the contribution of -OH functional groups. The -OH functional groups play a pivotal role in facilitating the adsorption of Na-ions and their sodiation into the HC lattice. During the initial five charge-discharge cycles, the HC_CNCx-Ch anode demonstrates a high reversibility. Specifically, HC_CNC6-Ch exhibits the highest discharge capacity, reaching 284 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, surpassing the discharge capacities of HC_CNC8-Ch (254 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), HC_CNC4-Ch (237 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), HC_CNC0-Ch (236 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), and HC_CNC10-Ch (226 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). By the fifth cycle, HC_CNC6-Ch achieves the highest reversible capacity of 244 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, maintaining a capacity retention of 86&nbsp;%. The range of irreversible capacity for all HC_CNCx-Ch variants lies between 14&nbsp;% to 21&nbsp;%, primarily attributable to the formation of the SEI layer, the entrapment of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a> within defects, and the presence of -NH/-OH functional groups. [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0335" name="bbb0335" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">67</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140"><span>Furthermore, the GCD profiles was employed to study the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> energy storage mechanism in HC. The total capacities of HC_P</span><em>V</em><span>DF and HC_CNCx-Ch originate from the combined contributions of plateau capacity and sloping capacity. The sloping capacity is observed within the voltage range of 2.5&nbsp;V to 0.1&nbsp;V, indicating the adsorption of Na-ions on the surface of HC or the filling of HC mesoporous. Conversely, the plateau capacity is identified through GCD profiles ranging from 0.1&nbsp;V to 0.01&nbsp;V, indicating sodiation process into graphene interlayer and <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopore from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopore</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. Notably, the capacity of HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch is predominantly governed by the plateau capacity. This mechanism aligns with that Jin et al. proposed [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0340" name="bbb0340" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0340"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">68</span></span></a>]. The ability of CNCx-Ch substrates in improving cycle stability of HC is due to the best synergy of -OH and -NH functional groups in adsorbing Na-ions and distributing them homogeneously on HC surfaces [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0345" name="bbb0345" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0345"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>]. The -OH functional group has a self-healing ability through strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding to maintain the integrity of HC particles during volume expansion and stabilize the SEI layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0350" name="bbb0350" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0350"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">70</span></span></a>]. Appropriate -OH substituents promote reversible sodiation and de-sodiation reaction [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0240" name="bbb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">Based on the GCD profile, it has been observed that incorporating 6&nbsp;wt% CNC exhibits the most favourable synergy with Ch in terms of enhancing the specific capacity, reversible capacity, and cyclic stability of HC. However, the addition of more than 6&nbsp;wt% CNC can lead to a decrease in capacity which is attributed to the high affinity of the -OH functional groups. These functional groups are prone to trapping a more significant number of Na-ions, leading to irreversible de-sodiation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0355" name="bbb0355" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0355"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">71</span></span></a>]. Despande et al. proved that Na-ions' interaction with cellulose without water is purely ionic [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0360" name="bbb0360" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0360"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">72</span></span></a>]. Therefore, it is crucial to control the CNC content in HC_CNC-Ch.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0150">The rate capability shows the reversible capacity of an electrode at different current density. Herein, the rate capability of the HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch anodes was performed at various current densities including 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (a). At a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, more Na-ions are stored in the HC material, which can be attributed to diffusion-dominant contribution. With increasing current density, there is inadequate time for Na-ions to effectively diffuse into the graphene layer. The specific capacity tends to decrease as the current density increases, resulting the higher polarization [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0075" name="bbb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>] which reduce the charge transfer Na<sup>+</sup>/Na. The reaction kinetics of Na-ions primarily occurs through pseudocapacitive mechanisms on the surface of HC, as well as within its pores or defects. This behavior is evident by the decline in specific capacity as the current density rises. The rate capability results demonstrate that both HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch exhibit favourable reversible capacity at current densities ranging from 25 to 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. HC-CNC10-Ch exhibit a higher specific capacity than HC_PVDF and among HC_CNCx-Ch at high current density due to the increased CNC contribution. The -OH functional group contribution of CNC provides the capacitive effect at the anode surface, resulting in higher capacity and cycle stability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0365" name="bbb0365" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0365"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">73</span></span></a>]. However, when the current density surpasses over 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the charge-discharge process becomes swift, leading to significant degradation in HC performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0370" name="bbb0370" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0370"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">74</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr6.jpg" height="191" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="ca0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (414KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (414KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0030"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. a) Rate capability at various current density from 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1 to 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1; b) cycle stability of HC_PVDF dan HC_CNCx-Ch at current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">The GCD profile results for 50&nbsp;cycles, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (b), at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g-1, reveal a significant reduction in the discharge capacity for HC_PVDF, dropping from 316 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 31 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. In the subsequent 50&nbsp;cycles at a current density of 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, only a retained capacity of 1.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is observed. This capacity fading is suspected to be due to the continuous growth of the SEI layer during cycling, associated with irreversible electrolyte decomposition and surface degradation of HC_PVDF. This result aligns with the increased R<sub>ct</sub> observed on the Nyquist plot after 100&nbsp;cycles. In contrast, HC_CNCx-Ch demonstrates superior electrochemical performance for up to 100&nbsp;cycles in terms of cycle stability, reversible capacity, and retained capacity compared to HC_PVDF, thanks to the -OH functional group in CNC which is effective for facilitating the Na<sup>+</sup> movement during the charge-discharge cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0375" name="bbb0375" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0375"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">75</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (b) shows that the highest electrochemical performance is achieved by HC_CNC6-Ch, which is in good agreement with its high reversible CV cycles (Fig. S6) and its lower R<sub>SEI</sub>/R<sub>ct</sub> after 100&nbsp;cycles (Fig. S7). HC_CNC6-Ch exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 285 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and decrease to 190 mAh g-1 at a current density of 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for 50&nbsp;cycles. Over the next 50&nbsp;cycles, as the current density is increased by 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, a retained capacity of 90 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (82&nbsp;%) is achieved. At the higher current density of 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, HC_CNCx-Ch showed the higher capacity than HC_PVDF as shown in Fig. S8. This higher electrochemical performance of HC_CNCx-Ch resembles with the previous finding by Fu et al. which regulate the electrode surface with -OH functional group-derived <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanocellulose" title="Learn more about nanocellulose from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanocellulose</a> to facilitate K-ion capture and improve transport kinetic, leading to increase its capacity and life-cycle [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. However, it is crucial to control the amount of CNC, as an excess of -OH groups may impede de-sodiation and lead to a reduction in capacity, as suggested by Mittal et al [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0345" name="bbb0345" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0345"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>]. In this study, the optimal electrochemical performance for HC was achieved with a 6&nbsp;% CNC contribution.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">The electrochemical behavior of HC_CNCx-Ch were further analyzed by CV techniques in the potential window of 0.01â€“2.0&nbsp;V using 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> (EC:DMC, 1:1) electrolyte. Fig. S6 displays the CV curves of the half-cell of HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch at scan rate of 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for 4&nbsp;cycles. Two sharp peaks are observed in the CV curves for both HC_PVDF and HC_CNCx-Ch, confirming the reversible sodiation/de-sodiation mechanism of Na<sup>+</sup>/Na in the graphene interlayer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165"><span class="display"><span id="fo0010" class="formula"><span class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2212;</mo></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; transform="scale(55.199) matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)">âž”</text></g><g is="true" transform="translate(12484,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4E"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-61" x="750" transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(16926,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(17927,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(722,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-38"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi is="true">de</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mtext is="true">sodiation</mtext><mo is="true">:</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">NaC</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub><mspace width="2em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">âž”</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mo is="true">âˆ’</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mi is="true">de</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mtext is="true">sodiation</mtext><mo is="true">:</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">NaC</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub><mspace width="2em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">âž”</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mo is="true">âˆ’</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">8</mn></msub></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">The reversible sodiation occurs at 0.01&nbsp;V, meanwhile, the reversible de-sodiation take places at 0.12&nbsp;V for HC_PVDF and 0.2â€“0.44&nbsp;V for HC_CNCx-Ch. The HC_CNC6-Ch, HC_CNC8-Ch, and HC_CNC10-Ch exhibited higher reversibility reactions, which showed by the overlapped CV profiles in subsequent cycles, corresponding with high-capacity retention of anode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0135" name="bbb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. The irreversible peak of HC_PVDF appears in the initial cathodic cycle, which is attributed to the electrolyte decomposition or SEI formation.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0180">Furthermore, the energy storage mechanism of HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch, can be predicted by determining the b-value from the log peak currents (i) vs log the scan rate (Ï…), as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(b) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(e), in accordance with Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0020" name="bfo0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a> and Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0025" name="bfo0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>. The Power law dependence of the current response was used to identify the anode kinetics based on CV curves at various scan rates from 0.2 to 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0380" name="bbb0380" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0380"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[76]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0385" name="bbb0385" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0385"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[77]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0390" name="bbb0390" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0390"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[78]</span></span></a>]. The total stored current (i) in HC is originated from: 1) the faradaic current in the HC bulk (i<sub>b</sub>), known as diffusion current, 2) the faradaic current on HC surface (i<sub>s</sub>), known as pseudocapacitive current, and 3) the nonfaradaic current of double layer effect [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0135" name="bbb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0390" name="bbb0390" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0390"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">78</span></span></a>].<span class="display"><span id="fo0020" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span transform="translate(8983,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28" x="0" y="0"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C5"></use></g><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29" x="930" y="0"></use></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">b</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi></mfenced></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-5"><math><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">b</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">log</mo><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi></mfenced></math></script></span></span></span><span>where the a and b are obtained by plotting log(i) versus log(Ï…). The b-value of 1 indicates a pseudocapacitive-dominated process, signifying fast surface <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> and double layer effect. Meanwhile, the b-value of 0.5 suggests a diffusion-dominated process, implying sodiation reaction within the HC lattice. The b-value of 0.75 is associated with the kinetics of the reaction proportionally contributed by both diffusion and pseudocapacitive-controlled process. For cathodic reaction, the calculated b-value of HC P</span><em>V</em>DF and HC_CNC6-Ch are 0.57 and 0.50, respectively, indicating the diffusion-dominated process. Meanwhile, for anodic reaction, the calculated b-value of HC PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch are 0.63 and 0.73, respectively, which indicate the kinetic anodic reaction governed by both diffusion and pseudocapacitive-controlled mechanisms.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr7.jpg" height="431" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="ca0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (553KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (553KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0035"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves at various scan rates from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> for a) HC_PVDF and d) HC_CNC6-Ch; the linier relationship between log i vs log Ï… for b) HC_PVDF and e) HC_CNC6-Ch; the capacity contribution at various scan rates from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for c) HC_PVDF and f) HC_CNC6-Ch.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">Further calculation of diffusion and pseudocapacitive contributions at a certain scan rate can be utilized Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0030" name="bfo0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a> and Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0035" name="bfo0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>. The total voltammetric current is the sum of the diffusion current and the pseudocapacitive current.<span class="display"><span id="fo0030" class="formula"><span class="label">(4)</span><span transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4288,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5344,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6327,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C5"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(540,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8251,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(9252,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">V</mi></mfenced><mo is="true">/</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-7"><math><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">V</mi></mfenced><mo is="true">/</mo><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï…</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></math></script></span></span></span>k<sub>1</sub>Ï… and k<sub>2</sub>Ï…<sup>1/2</sup> correspond to the current contribution from the pseudocapacitive process and the diffusion process, respectively. Using Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0035" name="bfo0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>, the constant k<sub>1</sub> and k<sub>2</sub> are evaluated from the slope and intercept of a linier plot of i(V)/Ï…<sup>1/2</sup> vs Ï…<sup>1/2</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a> (c) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a> (f) provide a quantitative analysis of the capacity contribution of HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch concerning increasing scan rate.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">At a scan rate of 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the electrochemical kinetics of HC_PVDF are primarily governed by a 78&nbsp;% diffusion-dominant process and a 22&nbsp;% pseudocapacitive process. The distinct sharp peak observed in the HC_P<em>V</em>DF anodic peak (at 0.12&nbsp;V) is associated with the de-sodiation reaction kinetics. Conversely, the broad peak in the HC_CNC6-Ch graph signifies an increase in pseudocapacitive kinetics, attributed to the presence of CNC. In the case of HC_CNC6-Ch, the contributions of pseudocapacitive and diffusion processes are 34&nbsp;% and 66&nbsp;%, respectively. In this regard, the -OH functional group in CNC trap Na-ions on the surface, resulting in an increased pseudocapacitive current through functional group adsorption and electrical double-layer formation. Zhifei et al. simulated that the bond energy of Na-ion at the surface involved 1.08&nbsp;eV, whereas at pristine HC, it achieved 0.529&nbsp;eV [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0395" name="bbb0395" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0395"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">79</span></span></a>]. As a result, the voltammetric current released in HC_CNC6-Ch tends to be lower than in HC_PVDF, resulting in a wider anodic peak. Furthermore, increasing the scan rate leads to a higher pseudocapacitive current (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(a)), derived from an increase in double-layer size due to the adsorption mechanism on the surface. Based on this reason, the results are aligned with the b-slope value of 0.73 in the anodic reaction, leading to an increase in pseudocapacitive contribution. This explains why the HC_CNC-Ch peak appears wider compared to HC_PVDF in the anodic peak range of 0.2â€“0.44&nbsp;V. This observation raises the suspicion that -OH functional groups strongly influence pseudocapacitive effects during the anodic reaction. Other researchers have demonstrated that oxygen functional groups enhance ion adsorption [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>] and induces surface capacitance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0235" name="bbb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0195">EIS measurements were performed to investigate the internal resistance of half-cell system both before and after cycling. The ohmic resistance or bulk resistance (R<sub>b</sub>) represents the resistance of electrolyte, separator, and current collector [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0400" name="bbb0400" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0400"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">80</span></span></a>]. The solid electrolyte interphase resistance (R<sub>SEI</sub>) is associated with a thin layer that forms over the anode surface during the initial charge-discharge and is generated by the decomposition of the electrolyte. On the surface of active material, charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) arises due to faradaic reactions. Another significant component, Warburg impedance (W), is the resistance linked to the diffusion process, typically observed at low frequencies around 20&nbsp;Hz to 0.01&nbsp;Hz. Conversely, R<sub>b</sub> is observed at high frequencies. The electrical double layer (EDL) is formed at the interface of SEI and the anode surface, manifesting a constant phase element (CPE). The presence of the CPE correlates with the EDL formation on the porous surface. The anode undergoes the electrochemical kinetics steps, namely: 1) ionic charge transfer through the electrolyte to the anode surface, 2) ion diffusion through the SEI layer, 3) charge transfer at the interlayer between the anode surface and SEI, 4) ionic diffusion inside the anode, 5) phase transfer leading to new phase transformations associated with the pseudocapacitive behavior of the anode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0405" name="bbb0405" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0405"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">81</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0200">The Echem Analyst software was utilized to analyze the EIS spectra in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>(a)<span> to determine the equivalent circuit model, which signifies the resistance encountered throughout the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a>. All anodes displayed low R</span><sub>b</sub><span> as indicated in Table S2, attributed to their lyophilic tendencies, which were determined through contact angle analysis (Fig. S11). HC_PVDF demonstrates excellent <a href="/topics/materials-science/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> with ester-based electrolytes, enhancing its reactivity with these electrolytes and facilitating the formation of a SEI layer. As a result, the resistance of HC_PVDF witnesses a significant increase after 100&nbsp;cycles. The R</span><sub>SEI</sub> surged from 43 Ohm to 722 Ohm, while the R<sub>ct</sub> rose from 12.55 Ohm to 363.7 Ohm. The growth of the SEI on HC_PVDF is evidenced by the decreased capacity seen in its GCD profile. Fig. S8(b) reveals several microcracks on the SEI surface, indicative of uncompensated volume expansion during cycling. In contrast, both R<sub>SEI</sub> and R<sub>ct</sub> for HC_CNC6-Ch only saw a sixfold increase after 100&nbsp;cycles. This indicates that the presence of the -OH functional group on HC_CNC6-Ch plays a crucial role in the surface chemistry of the HC anode, aiding in the stabilization of the SEI and charge transfer. The stable and homogenous SEI film on the HC_CNC6-Ch surface is depicted in Fig. S8. Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) analysis spots shows the accumulation of NaClO<sub>4</sub>, indicating the adsorption of NaClO<sub>4</sub> within the void spaces of the HC_CNC6-Ch (Fig. S9). In the Nyquist plot in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>(a), the SEI semicircles for both HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch are not distinctly visible, due to the semicircle curves of SEI and charge transfer overlapping.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X24010764-gr8.jpg" height="442" alt="Fig. 8" image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0040"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. a) Nyquist plot and equivalent electrical circuit model for HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch, b) Warburg coefficient of Z<sub>real</sub> against Ï‰<sup>-1/2</sup> before and after 100&nbsp;cycles of charge-discharge for HC_PVDF and HC_CNC6-Ch.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0205"><span>The Warburg impedance at low-frequency region were used to calculate the apparent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a>, The <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-9-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; A higher <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-10-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; Moreover, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-11-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.995ex" height="3.24ex" viewBox="0 -896.2 2581 1395" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.158ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g><g is="true"></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-11"><math><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace></math></script></span>can be determined by analyzing the oblique lines in the low-frequency section of Nyquist plot, following Eq. 6. and Eq. 7.<span class="display"><span id="fo0040" class="formula"><span class="label">(6)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-12-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Z</mi><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>real</mtext></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>s</mi></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>ct</mi></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C3;&amp;#x3C9;</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="24.46ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 10531.5 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" sinusoidal frequency (Ï‰&nbsp;=&nbsp;2Ï€f). The Ïƒ value is obtained from the slope of the linear plot of Z<sub>real</sub> vs. Ï‰<sup>-1/2</sup><sub>,</sub> as seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" the anode, the number <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about of electrons transfers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">of electrons transfers</a>, the Faraday constant, the Na-ions concentration, and Warburg coefficient, respectively. An increase in the Ïƒ value signifies a substantial reduction in the diffusion rate. At 100 charge-discharge cycles, the Ïƒ value of PVDF increased substantially from 39.45 to 857, whereas the Ïƒ value of HC_CNC6-Ch decreased substantially from 186 to 4.73.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0215">The determination of diffusion rate was also concluded through GITT analysis, in addition to the EIS method. To acquire quantitative values of the chemical diffusion coefficients of ions in solid electrodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0415" name="bbb0415" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0415"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">83</span></span></a>], the GITT method has been widely implemented. Following Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fo0050" name="bfo0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fo0050"><span current pulse time, total change of cell voltage during constant current pulse neglecting the IR-drop, change of the steady-state voltage, mass, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/density-specific-gravity" title="Learn more about molar volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar volume</a><span>, the <a of the electrode material, respectively. It may be noticing that m</span></span><sub>B</sub>V<sub>M</sub>/M<sub>B</sub> represents the volume of the electrode material. xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-19"><math><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">app</mi></msubsup></math></script></span>value than EIS method. Nevertheless, both approaches demonstrate that the Na-ions diffusion rate in HC_CNC6-Ch is comparatively slower than that in HC_PVDF during the initial stages of the cycle. However, after 100&nbsp;cycles, HC_CNC6-Ch exhibits a faster Na-ion diffusion rate than HC_PVDF.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot rowsep-0 colsep-0" id="t0005"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0050"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. The <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-20-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math
